PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that:

That a Government decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcaster) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, will place in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

2. We request that any changes to the Child Care Act should ensure the protection of these children by providing for quality care by mothercraft nurses or other trained child care professionals.

3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. Could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following petition, which is not in conformity with Standing Orders, from 12 petitioners requesting that the Senate reject the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator F. Bjelke-Petersen
C/o Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Madam,
In the next session of Parliament the proposed Bill of Rights will come before the Senate to be debated, we would like to voice our protest at the proposed Bill.
(1) Because of the haste with which this legislation was passed through the House of Representatives in view of the fact that it affects adversely areas of immense importance of liberty and freedom.

(2) Because it is based upon the United Nations International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights which has been rejected by the United States of America and Great Britain but was accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries.

(3) Because our Australian Constitution states that ``whereas the people'' give you, the government, these rights The Constitution limits the rights and power of government. The proposed Bill of Rights reverses this totally and states that ``we the government, give you the people these rights.'' This totally reverses the nature of government in this country. Our rights are now protected by current legislation, common law and the present Constitution.
(4) Because it transfers the power of interpretation of legislation from the Parliament of Australia (the democratically elected institution) to the Courts (an unelected body of people).

(5) Because the Bill of Rights will be administered by the Human Rights Commission which is an unelected body of people with powers which exceed the normal processes of law-no appeal, closed hearings, no legal representation.
We therefore request that you vote to reject this proposed Bill of Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-All of us are familiar with the comprehensive report prepared by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on the subject of a national language policy. That report has already been established as a basic document for all groups interested in the field.

SPEECH.PARA: I advised the Senate in May 1985 that as Minister for Education I had taken on the responsibility of co-ordinating the Government's response to the report. I indicated then that I hoped to announce that response by September 1985. Some time has passed since that statement. We have not wasted the time. I have been actively exploring ways to develop a coherent and comprehensive national language policy, and to ensure that that policy is as balanced, as sensible and as practical as possible. That approach seems to me to be preferable to dealing piecemeal with the numerous recommendations in the Senate report. We have made progress in many of the fields the Committee discussed, but we want to respond to the report as a whole and to present a fully formed policy for the consideration of honourable senators. That policy will be ready in the next few months. My Department has been examining the development and implementation of a policy. I have in mind some supplementary procedures as well, which will ensure that the policy fully reflects the views of groups involved in this field and is properly co-ordinated with government programs in all the areas concerned.

In finalising our recommendations and judgments, we will be consulting widely. We will invite comments about the policy as presented and will hold further consultations about methods for implementation. No group need worry that its views will be neglected or passed over. I hope that our preferred approach will attract bipartisan support. The issue of language policy is too broad and too sensitive to be the subject of partisan squabbling. That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, as its Chairman, I thank the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) for the statement she has made on the forthcoming response to the Committee's national language policy report. I am grateful also for the Minister's kind remarks about the quality of the report. Members of the Committee spent a great deal of time in its preparation. Time was taken in examining submissions, speaking to concerned groups throughout the community, conducting public hearings and in the production of the report. The Committee recognised that it should place before the Senate a report which properly reflected the extensive views put to it by those interested in many language areas. Once the Committee had submitted its report it looked forward to a response from the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not surprising that a comprehensive reply has not yet been presented by the Government, for it should be remembered that the Committee's work was carried out over two years. Admittedly, some time was lost when the Parliament was dissolved in 1983, but the duration of the inquiry gives an indication of the report's wide scope. Nevertheless, I would urge the Minister to bring forward the Government's response in the next few months, as she has mentioned. There is a keen interest in the community for progress to go now beyond the Committee's reporting stage. I do not suggest for a moment that the Minister and her officers have not made progress, but interested groups are eagerly awaiting some tangible evidence of the Government's consideration of the numerous recommendations in the report.

On behalf of the Committee and the many people who provided the Committee with their experience and advice, I express the hope that the Government's response will be available before the winter recess. I am pleased that the Minister has indicated that she has gone beyond the Committee's report and is examining some supplementary procedures to enhance the policy which is being developed. The Committee, and I expect the Senate, is looking forward to the Government's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition recognises that the interim statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has very much promised that the Government's response will eventually be positive and constructive towards the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. The Minister's emphasis that the report is already established `as a basic document for all groups interested in the field', to quote her words, is I am sure well received by honourable senators. But the disappointment in interested groups throughout Australia and in the Senate lies in the slowness of the Government's response. The report was put down in December 1984, some 15 months ago, and the inquiry was begun in May 1982. Therefore, almost four years have elapsed, with public interest having been sustained throughout those four years.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Minister said originally that she hoped to respond on the Government's behalf by September last year, hopes were again raised that this comprehensive response would be in the hands of all the interested parties some six months ago, but now when the Minister refers to a comprehensive response within the next few months, I take this to mean, and I believe the Senate can take it to mean, about three months from now, in early May. That would be exactly four years since the inquiry began here in the Senate. I appeal to the Minister not to have any more interim statements. I hope that every effort can be made to come down with a substantial report by early May this year. Patience has already been running thin and because of that, as the Minister knows, on Sunday there will be a major conference here in Canberra of interested groups from ethnic communities, language academics and others who will be seeking to confirm ways to press the Government to give priority to responding fully to the report and to implements its findings.

I note particularly in this statement the Minister's promises. In order to meet the growing disappointment and frustrated expectation on the part of the public, the Minister has felt the need to invest her statement with hope and promise and to keep expectations high until we receive the whole response early in May. It is clear that we do not prefer, as the Minister said, to have a piecemeal, partial response but we look for a comprehensive response from the Government that will deal with all the 15 chapters and 117 recommendations. Further, the Minister has assured us in the statement that she and the Government will be consulting widely and setting up procedures which will ensure, to quote her words, `that the policy fully reflects the views of groups involved in this field'. I welcome that promise and I am sure that the conference at the weekend will take great heart from it.

I know that our ethnic communities all around Australia are keenly interested in taking up the promise to involve them in consultation, as are language academics, applied linguists, modern language teachers' associations, linguistics associations, all teaching departments, teachers of English-there are several major chapters on English in the report-teachers of English as a second language and people involved in the adult migrant education program. Of course, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has put down the report entitled `Towards Active Voice' which already is the beginning of a response by the Government to some of the statements in the report.

Those concerned with adult literacy will be wanting to take up the promise made by the Minister for Education in her statement. I believe that Aboriginal communities-their linguists, teachers, interpreters, translators and media people, all of whom are referred to in the report-will seek the consultation that the Minister has proffered today. The associations which speak for those with communication handicaps-the deaf and the blind-and those with speech disorders as well as the physically and intellectually disabled will be interested in what the Minister has had to say. Other people interested in the Minister's statement will be those involved in Australia's diplomacy, trade and foreign relations who use regional and international languages in their professional work.

The teachers of second languages, perhaps more than anybody else, will want to take up the Minister's promise. As the Senate will know, about 100 second languages are taught in primary, secondary and tertiary education institutions and also through ethnic schools and ethnic community projects. Also, those in specialist professions such as translators and interpreters, some of whom are employed in government departments all around Australia, will want to take up the promise made by the Minister today. Last but not least, the Minister's statement will be of interest to librarians who have an active involvement with books and other resources in all the relevant languages which are of interest to those who use our libraries in the cities, suburbs and towns of Australia. I also believe that people involved in the media and the arts-not just persons working for the Special Broadcasting Service and ethnic radio-will find promise in the Minister's statement and will want actively to pursue what the Minister has said. All of the groups of which we are aware will want to play their part in a co-ordinated national language policy.

The promises that the Minister has given them today will be taken to heart by many people in Australia. I would not like to predict the thunderous disapproval if there is further delay or if the response fails to live up to what the Minister said in her very good statement. The Minister is straightforward in acknowledging that the Senate report has become the basic document in this field. I thank the Government for this foundation acknowledgement. I am sure that not only Senator Colston, Senator Giles, Senator Robert Ray and Senator Reynolds, who now sit on the Government side of the Senate, but also Senator Peter Baume and Senator Reid, who now sit with me on the Opposition side, all of whom contributed so positively to this major report, agree with the remarks that I am making.

The Minister has called for continuing bipartisan support from the Opposition side and that support is still there. However, I say again that we expect that there will not be any more interim statements but a positive, comprehensive response by about early May. If there is less than a full response I am sure that those people who will come from all parts of Australia to attend the conference at the weekend will devise a strategy to cope with the situation.

Finally, I stress to the Senate and to the Minister, who is warmly sympathetic to the goals of the report, that one can test whether the eventual response will succeed or fail. I refer to the two global recommendations Nos 1 and 2 that precede all the other 100 or so detailed recommendations in the report. The Government's response will fail if it does not directly endorse the four guiding principles set out in recommendation No. 1. I will read that brief but global recommendation in full:
Language policies should be developed and co-ordinated at the national level on the basis of four guiding principles, namely:
competence in English;
maintenance and development of languages other than English;
provision of services in languages other than English;
opportunities for learning second languages.
The second part of this test comes under recommendation No. 2 which is:

A national advisory council on language policy should be established, conferred with advisory, co-ordinating and policy research functions. The council should be broadly representative of all bodies involved with language policy but not so large as to function inefficiently and should report regularly to both Commonwealth and State Governments.

This crucial, essential and fundamental recommendation needs to be implemented. The establishment of this council, more than any other recommendation of the report, will be the litmus test of the Government's positive response to the report. As the Minister knows, the Senate Committee has deliberately, and I think wisely, expressed this recommendation in general terms. We have not sought to bind the Government hand and foot in defining the constitution of that council. However, we see it as an essential body to be established because it will be the major vehicle for monitoring and advising on the implementation of all the 100 or so recommendations that follow. This national advisory council will be the guardian of a national language policy in the coming years in Australia.

In conclusion, I thank the Minister for all of her positive promises and for the commitment to consult widely in these final weeks. I know that some drafts of the Government's response have already been circulated and found wanting in a number of serious respects. I again welcome the Government's response to those consultations-to go back and get it right. All of us in the Senate are patient to the extent that the Government will take note of those consultations and make sure that the response by early May will meet the challenge of the whole of the report. The challenge now is that that response be balanced, sensible and a practical implementation of what the Senate Committee has found.

We know that all these joy-stick jockeys such as Senator MacGibbon, Senator Sanders and Senator Townley-that is, if he has not had his licence taken off him-jazz around the airports, do wheelies and so on. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume said that we cannot have a word such as `detrimental' in a piece of legislation because it is not clearly defined. We have had debates in this place for hours on end on the meaning of the words `that' and `the'. When the late Senator Greenwood and Senator Murphy were here they used to argue and debate the meanings of what to the rest of us were pretty clear words. Of course we can put the word `detrimental' in a piece of legislation. The lawyers are paid big money to define what the words mean. We sit here and argue and define what they mean. The legislation also points out that as far as non-aviation buildings are concerned-and that is what Senator Sanders is talking about in his amendment; buildings not directly related to aviation-the Corporation and the people running the airport should take into account the laws and building regulations of the councils around the airport, provided that they do not interfere with the conduct of their activities and their responsibilities in conducting that airport.

We should not be worried about putting that sort of thing in. TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you want to pick on the people of Launceston again.

One of the problems with legislation that comes out of this Parliament is that, unlike the Congress of the United States or parliaments of some other democracies, we never state at the start of legislation what we are supposed to be about. SPEECH.PARA: So I ask honourable senators not to be too unkind to Senator Sanders and not to say the unkind things that they have said about him. Maybe he has actually introduced a principle in here that is all right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply just briefly. I know some people are pretty thick. Senator Sanders made the point that of course people complain about small planes flying over. I talked about the citizens of Launceston who write to me all the time complaining about freight planes going over every night. That does not mean, nor could it in anyone's wildest imagination mean, that the intention or result of Senator Sanders's amendment about noise would be that the Government would have to spend hundreds of thousands of millions of dollars relocating airports. SPEECH.PARA: The Corporation shall endeavour to perform its functions in a manner that-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has been anticipating the commencement of the debate on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill and cognate Bills for two or three days. At long last we commence a very important and apparently-I make no apologies for this-very long debate on the package of legislation introduced by the Government which has become known as the human rights package. However, my main attention will be devoted to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill which, of course, is the centrepiece of this package. At the same time I should state that the Opposition will oppose the whole package. It is strongly opposed to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and we will vote against it. We hope that the Senate will agree with our view and not that of the Government, whatever the Government's view might be because it seems likely that there will be changes in the Government's view if it gives way to pressures from a number of its left-wing supporters.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage, the Opposition opposes the Bills in their present form. Any changes that might be made by the Government would only further offend the Opposition, so there is not much chance of us reaching agreement with the Government on this matter. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, transitional Bills and amending Bills-all parts of the package-will be opposed by the Opposition, but not because we are opposed to human rights. We are opposed only to the changes which are being proposed by the Government to the existing Human Rights Commission. If I have time, I will give some reasons why we oppose those changes.

Of course, there has been a very lengthy debate about proposals for a Bill of Rights, both in this country and in many other countries. The human rights movement has gathered momentum, particularly since World War II, and there has been a good deal of movement on that issue in the United Nations. As part of that movement the United Nations adopted the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in 1966, that being really the centrepiece of this international debate. But, of course, the question of a guaranteed Bill of Rights, however we refer to it, has a very much longer tradition that that. It goes back to the United States of America's Constitution and the various amendments to that Constitution which have become famous because of the widespread publicity and the application that they have had around the world over the last 200 years.

As far as countries with our traditions of democracy, of a strong, independent judiciary and of common law are concerned, the debate has really centred upon whether it is desirable or necessary to have a constitutionally guaranteed Bill of Rights, in other words, a Bill which is an overriding law which all courts must obey despite what the parliaments-of course, in democratic countries these are fully representative parliaments-may decide the laws should be. Ultimately, the laws are judged not by a Parliament, not by the elected representatives, but by judges. There has been a great deal of debate and criticism about the extent to which judges become legislators. I suppose the high point of that movement was the Warren court in the United States with the really quite incredible number of judgments emanating from that court over a few years which made very major changes to the laws of the United States and which are having a widespread effect on the everyday living of the people of the United States. Of course, there has now been very great reaction to that sort of interventionist role for judges. That is one of the great concerns that have always been held by people who oppose the entrenching of a Bill of Rights in a constitution.

Let me state that this Bill of Rights Bill does not seek to amend the Australian Constitution or to require all the parliaments of Australia, Federal and State, to observe its guarantees. It does not even do that for Federal laws. What it does is introduce directly into the Federal legal system, and indirectly into the State legal system as I will show, the provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which, as I said, was drawn up in the United Nations in 1966. In my view, although no doubt there can be debate about this, this is a quite inappropriate way to introduce into our legal and political systems any notion of a Bill of Rights, of a guarantee of those rights to be binding on all parliaments at all times.

This is simply a backdoor method of achieving the purposes of the proponents of the Bill of Rights. As I have said, the Bill does not achieve any guarantee. But in a somewhat devious, dubious way, in the process of time if the Government's plans are fully implemented, it will introduce in effect, if not as a guaranteed law, the rules of the International Covenant on Civil Rights and Political Rights.

We have to ask ourselves two questions which are fundamental to this debate. The first is: Do we want to have a Bill of Rights? If the answer to that is yes, surely such a Bill of Rights should be drawn up with regard to Australian aspirations, needs and interests in 1986. We should not slavishly follow those provisions contained in the International Covenant, drawn up in the United Nations and greatly influenced by the many countries with no tradition of democracy at all that have set out these sorts of guarantees in that forum. I do not believe it is appropriate at all that Australia should seek to guarantee simply those rules. When the debate about human rights in Australia developed some years ago it was always intended that Australian parliaments should endeavour to reach agreement about the guarantees appropriate and relevant to modern Australia. All this international covenant contains is the lowest common denominator of rights that could be agreed upon in the United Nations, but certainly almost all the members of the United Nations did not then and do not now practise those rights. I will explain in a minute the deficiencies of this Bill in that regard.

Secondly, if we are to have an effective and properly supported Bill of Rights should it be introduced in this devious and dubious way by the Parliament under the grossly expanded power that it recently received by a four to three majority of the High Court of Australia? We should not go about it in this way at all. It should be put to the people at a referendum. If we are to have a proper Bill of Rights the people themselves should decide whether they want such a Bill of Rights and whether they approve of the Bill submitted to them by the Parliament. Such a fundamental change in our political and legal system should not be made in a backdoor way; it should be done in a straightforward open way and the people should be asked about it.

An excellent example of the Government's attitude is the way it has promoted this Bill of Rights. One of the centrepieces of its election promises before its election in 1983 was that it would introduce a Bill of Rights. When Senator Evans was Attorney-General he had his version of the Bill of Rights drafted. He circulated it to a few groups who he thought might give it some support or have some interest in it, but he would never make it public. When the election was called in 1984 he still refused to make it public despite a lot of pressure from this chamber that that be done. During the election campaign neither Senator Gareth Evans nor Prime Minister Hawke would unveil or reveal what their Bill of Rights contained. The very last thing this Government wants is any judgment by the people on what it is doing and what it is proposing in order to govern the people for virtually all time. The Government has drawn up legislation and it has deprived the people of making any judgment upon it. The way the legislation has been drafted and submitted will deprive the people-as far as the Government can achieve this-of ever making any judgment on it.

The Government is trying in this legislation to prevent future parliaments, as far as it possibly can, from ever altering or making any judgment on its proposal for a Bill of Rights. This Bill states that Australian Federal laws are to be interpreted by courts-all courts, of course, either Federal of State-and all courts are to be bound by this law which will be like any other Federal law. The Government has tried to give it a guarantee by saying that the courts have to interpret all past and future laws and they have to adopt an interpretation which, as far as possible, is consistent with the Bill of Rights. That is the first thing they have to do. If they find they cannot do that and the law is inconsistent with the Bill of Rights that law will become invalid in due course. There are some differences as to when past and future laws operate but that is all technical stuff that I will not go into.

This Bill of Rights has a very dangerous and strange provision that any future law passed by this Parliament will be governed by the Bill of Rights-it has to be interpreted, as far as possible, as being consistent with the Bill of Rights-unless there are express words of plain intendment which exclude the application of the Bill of Rights to that law. I think it is a dangerous assault on what has been a centrepiece of our Constitution that no parliament can or should endeavour to impose its views on its successors or bind its successors. Of course, whether or not this is a valid law will be decided in another place. I am not so worried about whether it is or is not a valid law. I am saying that it is certainly not politically and morally valid because it is quite contrary to the whole tradition of parliamentary democracy in this country and this is a classic example of how this Government went about changing, in this devious way, the nature of our Constitution without giving the people of Australia any say on it. As I have said, this Government would not even tell the people before the last election what it had in mind and what it had in store for them. It was too scared to have the people judge it. It is too scared now to have the people judge it. No wonder when we look at what it is proposing to be a statement of our fundamental rights.

The rights that are contained in this Bill, which are based on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, are unexception- able rights. Whether they are very meaningful to Australia in 1986 is another matter because they have all been part and parcel of our legal and political system for 200 years. They have been developed in the British political and legal system for many hundreds of years. No parliament in Australia would ever openly and consciously remove the sorts of rights that are set out in the covenant. So for the Government to be making a fuss about guaranteeing them now in this way is really a lot of eyewash.

Just when we want to talk about the relevance of these rights to modern Australia we find an article in the covenant which states that no person shall be held in slavery or servitude or be required to perform forced or compulsory labour. Has any Parliament in our political history ever been intent on breaching that guarantee? As I have said, this Government really does not add anything to the guarantees that we have enjoyed, that we are enjoying and that we will continue to enjoy as long as we have a healthy democracy in this country and as long as we have elections where people are able to make a choice between governments and where governments really tell the people what they propose to do after they are elected. The only threat we have to our system in this country is the way in which this Government and the Prime Minister who leads it tell the people that, if they are elected, interest rates will go down, there will be no capital gains taxes, petrol prices will go down and so on. They make these reckless promises. That is where the threat to democracy is in this country, not because Australian politicians are likely to be breaching these fundamental rules that we have all observed for decades and indeed centuries.

Honourable senators should bear in mind that this International Covenant was drawn up in 1966 in the United Nations which is largely composed of dictatorships of the Right or Left and, as I have said, some of them are of a fairly murderous disposition. This International Covenant does not contain any clear right to own private property. There is some suggestion that the Covenant may be interpreted in that way but no clear and unequivocal right is laid down to own private property and not to have it taken away without compensation as the Wran Government has tried to do in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —And successfully did it.

—And successfully did it, and it has not yet paid any compensation. Nor does this Covenant contain any right for parents to send their children to the school of their choice. Although this Covenant is very long on the right to form trade unions, it does not guarantee any right of a person not to be forced into joining a trade union. We know perfectly well that the policy of the Australian Labor Party and of many governments in Australia has been to force people to join trade unions. There is no guarantee of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have three very good, clear examples of matters which are of great moment to Australians. Modern Australians hold very dearly to these principles and these rights of owning property, of getting compensation if it is acquired for some public purpose, of being able to send their children to a school of their choice or, for that matter, to go to a doctor of their choice. These are rights which are not to be dragooned either by laws or by overwhelming, strong-arm, militant union tactics to force people to join or to remain members of a trade union. There is no clear working whatsoever in this legislation to protect any of those rights. Yet here we have the Government saying `We want to have a guarantee of rights in 1986 which Australians are entitled to enjoy', yet it does not make any attempt to put it in the legislation. The way the Government is going about this presents difficulties for it but that is its business; it is not our worry. Our worry is that we will have imposed upon us a totally inadequate statement of the rights which fulfil the needs, interests and aspirations of modern Australia. If the Senate does not throw this Bill out, as we hope it will, the Opposition will be moving a number of amendments along the lines which have already been circulated. But I will not go into that in any more detail.

There is another important objection to this Bill. I have already indicated how it will operate at the political and parliamentary level. Let me now deal with how it will operate at the judicial level. We will be asking judges of the Federal Court to decide the meaning of these extraordinarily broad general statements by which all legislation of this Parliament in future, and indeed past laws, will be judged. The judges will have to say whether our attempts in this Parliament to give effect to these guarantees are in conformity with these extremely generalised statements. I instance the phrase `right to life'-another one that is left up in the air. Article 18 reads:
Every human being has the inherent right to life and no person shall be arbitrarily deprived of life.

There is no indication whether that applies to human life before as well as after birth. Presumably it will be thrown on the judges to decide that question. That is one of the most, probably the most, sensitive and important decisions that have to be made, and of course it is the duty of this Parliament to make those decisions. It should not be thrust upon judges, who are unelected and remote from the affairs of everyday people.
There are some other most extraordinary provisions contained in the Bill about the role of judges. There is a clause that reads:
The rights and freedoms set out in this Bill are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.

Who will decide that? The judges will decide what limitations can be demonstrably justified. Who will demonstrate it? Will it be the Solicitor-General in argument before the Federal Court? Will he be the one to demonstrate it? It is not to be done by the Government, Ministers, parliamentarians or elected persons, but the Solicitor-General or the senior Queen's Counsel employed by the Government will have to demonstrate whether it is or is not justified in a free and democratic society. What a bonanza for the Bars of this country! What a bonanza the lawyers will get, as they do out of most legislation that comes from this Government.

I cite another beauty which is even better. If the judges find that the legislation is in conflict with the Bill of Rights, they are asked to say whether any grave public inconvenience or hardship might follow from a finding of that kind. If the judges find that there is a grave public inconvenience or hardship, apart from finding that an Act is in conflict with the Bill of Rights, the judge can suspend its operation. He can say that a law which has operated for years will not operate any longer. Because it is in conflict with the Bill of Rights and cannot be demonstrably shown to be justified in a free and democratic society, its past operation will still be able to apply because of the grave public hardship and inconvenience that might follow. As for the future, the judge can suspend his decision to enable something to be done about it. Really! It is incredible that this power is being given to judges. These are the sorts of decisions we are making which go to the very heart of democracy. It is the elected representatives of the people here in Parliament who should be making those decisions, not the unelected judges.

I have not the time to sum up my argument about the Bill of Rights. I must refer briefly to the Human Rights Commission. We are opposed to the greatly expanded role of the Human Rights Commission which this legislation gives. We are opposed to the fact that the Commission is to be turned by the Government into some great new souped-up bureaucracy. It is not to remain only a small advisory body as we set up when we were in government, a body with a small budget to advise government on human rights matters and whether legislation conformed with human rights requirements, and so on. The present Government has been greatly expanding the Human Rights Commission. Its budget over three years from 1983 to 1986 has trebled; Its staff has nearly doubled and there will be a huge increase in the future. The policy of this Government is to set up full time human rights commissioners and not to retain the important element that was in the existing Human Rights Commission involving part-time commissioners who were there because of their particular interest in, knowledge of the relations with people-disabled people, Aborigines or whatever. There may be people who are discriminated against or in some way not benefiting from the full enjoyment of life in common with the rest of the nation.

Under this Bill the Human Rights Commission will lose that human touch. It has already been developing a somewhat unnecessary bureaucracy. It is showing signs of going that way and the Government is encouraging it with this great increase in expenditure, staff and so on. Already a human rights bureaucracy is being established. These proposals will just accelerate the process. The vast new responsibilities under this legislation will give an excuse for that to accelerate. We are to have virtually another department of the Commonwealth administering this legislation.

There is already some legislation, such as the Sex Discrimination Act, and the Racial Discrimination Act, which has to be administered, but this Bill will greatly expand that whole role and that whole bureaucracy. The Bill also proposes that inquiries by the Human Rights Commission can be made into State as well as Federal laws. We are heading towards a major confrontation with the States as a result of this proposal, which is quite inconsistent with the Opposition's view of a federal system and its working. For all those reasons, many and various as they are, the Opposition will be opposing this whole package. If the Senate does not agree with us in that, we shall be moving some major amendments to the Bill in Committee. In that event, I believe that the Senate should be looking to refer the matter to a committee for further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by offering to the Senate the following quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major concerns of the Government is to preserve, improve and expand civil liberties in Australia insofar as the Commonwealth has power to do so.

That is a quotation with which most people in this chamber would agree. Those words were uttered by Senator Durack on 20 October 1976, when speaking on civil liberties in Australia. With great skill and compassion he was doing what he could to preserve those liberties. Indeed, the then Government and the coalition to which he belongs have a proud history in this field. It was under that Government or its successors that the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights was brought into operation. It is all very grand for Senator Durack to get up now and say, as he did today, that this Bill of Rights is full of defects. It is based on the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which he now says is not apt for Australia. He now says that this is not the sort of covenant we need for Australia and that we should have something different. Why did not those who preceded him in the coalition government take the same view?

The history of this matter is very interesting. The United Nations was created on 26 June 1945 and on 10 December 1948 its General Assembly proclaimed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, to which Australia is a party. The Australian Labor Party was then in government. What is interesting is that in the 1950s a commission on human rights with an Australian component was established. That Australian component was put there by Mr Menzies, the founder of the Party to which Senator Durack belongs. On this commission Australia sat with other nations throughout the 1950s developing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Senator Durack now disowns and says is not apt for Australia. We might ask Senator Durack why it was appropriate for Australia in the 1950s and 1960s to show interest in an international covenant but it is not appropriate for Australia now. Where has the big change taken place?

On 16 December 1966, when Mr Holt was the Prime Minister and the coalition was in power, 106 countries, including Australia, unanimously agreed to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. What has changed since then? Did the coalition, which was then in power, tell the people of Australia what it was about? On 18 December 1972 Mr Whitlam, who was then in power leading an Australian Labor Party government, signed the Covenant. But when was the Covenant, which is now said by the Opposition to be an outrage upon the Australian people, ratified? It was ratified on 13 August 1980 when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister and-correct me if I am wrong-when Senator Durack was the Attorney-General. Was there then a cry from the then Government that the Covenant was an assault upon the liberties of the Australian people, that the document was useless and should not be ratified? What change has taken place between 13 August 1980 and now? Why did the coalition Government then in power attach the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights as a Schedule to the Human Rights Commission Bill which was then passed, which Covenant it now turns its back on and says is inappropriate and proper only, if at all, for countries less blessed than Australia?

The big question to ask-I will be interested to hear what Opposition speakers say about this matter-is: Why was the International Covenant, which according to Senator Durack has suddenly become a pariah, attached to the coalition Government's 1981 Bill? What in Australia has changed since then to make that Covenant inappropriate? When yells and screams are heard in this debate, I would be very interested to hear why the Covenant was attached to that Bill. Why did Senator Durack, who was then the Attorney-General, attach the Covenant which he now so strongly attacks to the Human Rights Commission Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a guide for politicians. It was not going to become an overriding law. It is completely different.

—Senator Durack has missed the point I am making. He said in his address to the Senate-he may look at Hansard later-and certainly made clear that the Covenant was a pariah in Australia, that it was useless and not the sort of document that should be adopted. He said that if we are to have a Bill of Rights it ought to be based on something more apt and appropriate for Australia. All I want to know is: Since 1981 when the Bill was put through, what has suddenly made this Covenant, which Senator Durack now attacks, so worthy of attack when, in those days--
—If you look back you will know that the State and Federal Attorneys-General were working on the development of an Australian Bill themselves. You should have carried on that work.
—I understand all that.
—Ask your Minister why he did not carry on that work.

—I do not see that that goes to the point I am now asking, which is why under a government of which Senator Durack was a member and in which he was Attorney-General was there attached-it is there for all to see-to the Bill that set up the Human Rights Commission as Schedule 1, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Human Rights Commission Act has been sold all around the country. Its concepts have been put into operation to some extent by the Human Rights Commission which the previous Government set up.
—It gave it power to investigate and report on breaches of the terms of the Covenant.

—I thank Senator Evans. He is absolutely correct. The previous Government gave the Commission powers to examine matters in the light of the International Covenant which, as I remember-perhaps Senator Evans can correct me-was not put to the people of Australia by way of a referendum or for discussion. Why is it that when the coalition goes out of government and the Labor Party comes in and tries to continue the work the coalition government was doing-let us be clear about that-the Bill has its genesis in what the coalition set in operation--
—The reason is that we preserved the power of the Parliament. We were not trying to destroy it, like you.

—Let us get on to that. Senator Durack says that we are going to destroy the power of the Parliament by setting up a Bill of Rights. He says that the sorts of rights we are setting up in the Bill of Rights which we are going to bring before the people of Australia will curtail the ability of this Parliament to pass laws. We disagree with that concept, but it is a worthy argument. As the next point of Senator Durack's argument he goes on to say that, anyhow, the Bill is not needed because the Parliament is already bound by tradition not to do those things. The concepts set out in the Bill of Rights are very elementary and no parliament would dare breach them.

SPEECH.PARA: I again ask: What is the difference between being bound by tradition and by the lifestyle and culture we have in this country and setting out those concepts in documentary form? Does the honourable senator disagree with the Ten Commandments? They were written down. Would he say: `My God, why do we have the Ten Commandments written down'? We should not be following the Ten Commandments because they bind people in writing. They stop the Parliament from operating as it should simply because they are written down? One cannot have it both ways. One cannot say that there is a common law tradition in this country which stops the Parliament from breaching the laws that are set out, which is all right, and then say that the Bill is not all right because it stops the Parliament in writing from doing what it is already not able to do. In my view that is a quite inconsistent argument.

The Opposition goes on to talk about the right not to join a trade union, the right to send children to certain schools, and what have you. The Opposition has said that these are elementary rights. The Bill of Rights provides that the rights set out are rights that can be enforced only against the Commonwealth and Commonwealth officers. As Senator Durack well knows, under this Bill they are not rights that can be enforced in any way against the ordinary citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would your Government do if the Human Rights Commission told it that a State law was in conflict and ought to be changed?

—If the Human Rights Commission said that a State law was in conflict, this Government could not do anything, because under the Act the Commission would have to report to the Attorney-General who would have to bring that report to the Parliament which, hopefully, would discuss it. If the Commission brought to this Parliament a report which said that electoral boundaries or divisions were not fair in the sense that each person was not guaranteed a right of voting which was equal to everybody else's right of voting, this Parliament would say that that was a bad sort of thing and that it ought to be adjusted.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the United States, which again is a common law country whose culture and aspirations the Opposition and Australians generally would say set the proper standards. Cases such as Baker v. Carr and Wesberry v. Sanders, which I have no doubt Senator Durack has read and read again, the Opposition I hope would see as setting out the sorts of concepts which ought to be brought into this country, particularly the one that everybody should have an equal vote before the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you advocate your Government do if you get a report which says that a State law is in conflict with the Bill?

—I will tell the honourable senator what I would advocate. In meeting its international obligations and enacting into law the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, it ought to make a law which would be enforced by the High Court of Australia-I will come back to that-obliging the States, as the Supreme Court of America obliged States such as Tennessee-to provide for fair elections based on one vote one value. I will take the honourable senator up on what he said about that matter. The honourable senator stated in his speech-I sympathise with it-that as long as we have fair elections there is no need for a Bill of Rights. If the Opposition would say that it, as a future government, is intent on putting into operation throughout Australia a fair electoral system, a lot of the sting would go out of this debate on the Bill of Rights.
—What would Brian Burke have to say about that?
—If Brian Burke or any other Premier or politician of whatever colour advocates a situation in which people would not get equal rights, I hope I would have the strength to say that he is wrong.
—That's not the point.
—What is the point?
—What's Brian Burke going to say if you try to force your electoral system on him?
—The honourable senator has said--
—What would you propose the Parliament do?

—Does the honourable senator want to listen to the answer or not? Senator Durack said-these are his words or very close to them; honourable senators could look at Hansard later-that as long as we have fair elections there is no need for a Bill of Rights. The honourable senator would have to agree that there are parts of Australia in which fair elections do not take place and if he were fair dinkum he would say that there ought to be a Bill of Rights since that is in fact a situation which calls for it. That is the reverse side of the very proposition he put and flows from it.
—Where aren't there fair elections?
—Queensland, and the upper House of Western Australia.

—That is right. Senator Durack is obliged, if his statements now and the statements he made in 1976 hold any water at all, to advocate that a lot more ought be done in reference to the upper House in Western Australia, and the Parliament of Queensland, as Senator Haines has said, to make them houses elected on a fair and equal basis. Perhaps then there would not be so great a need as there is at present for a Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up another matter now. By inference, Senator Durack-I am sure if one got him in the cold light of day and said `Do you really mean this?', he would say `No, I don't'-made a subtle but quite strong attack on the judiciary. By and large, the judiciary of Australia has served this country very well indeed and in the traditions of the great common law system of England. For a former Attorney-General, by inference, to denigrate the judicial system is not apt: In fact, it is not good at all. In effect, Senator Durack said that the judiciary is not capable of interpreting in a fair way words in an Act of Parliament. Senator Durack quoted words in a roundabout way, almost in a sniggering way, and asked how the judiciary can decide what is demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society, saying that this Bill will allow the judiciary to decide what is and what is not right in those terms.

If we do not have this Bill, what do we rely on? One of the propositions that Senator Durack was putting was that we should rely on the common law. The common law is a magnificent thing. Of course, the common law is a judge-made law and has been very much so over many years. What is the difference between judges making the law through the common law procedure and through interpreting a statute? I would like the speakers who follow me to tell me how they make the subtle distinction involved in saying: `It is all right for judges to ``make'' our laws by way of the common law procedure but it is not all right for them to undertake the much more restricted task of ``making'' it by interpreting a Bill of Rights?' The two things just do not hold together. What is the difference between a judge making the common law through deciding cases-and we say the common law system protects our rights-and a judge giving an interpretation to the Bill of Rights enacted to protect those rights? Why should it be wrong for judges to interpret a statute aimed at protecting rights and yet all right for them to make laws again and again through common law procedures?

Senator Durack said that surely the Bill of Rights should be drawn up in terms of the needs of Australia in 1986. The inference in that statement is that we should be selfish. An international covenant has been developed worldwide to try to establish a basis for humanity in the world, a basic set of rights. We as a nation of the world, should be able to say at the very least that we have legislation expressing rights that the world regards as basic.

However, Senator Durack says: `We should not be looking after the rest of the world. Let the people in the East and West, in both ``good'' and ``bad'' countries, do what they will because we will not join in an international covenant to bring human rights to everybody'. We have to become an island. We have to be terribly selfish in Australia. We have to ignore the plight of somebody in Bulgaria, Central America, Pakistan or wherever. We will not enter into an international covenant which may give people around the world who are being tortured and maimed some comfort that at least there is a universally recognised minimum of rights and that certain countries at least can be identified as having legislated to protect them by law. Senator Durack says that we should forget about all that and that we should look at things simply and wholly in terms of Australians and Australians only. In my view that is a very selfish and very narrow attitude which is not worthy of Australia as a member of the international community. Australia, under the coalition Government, entered into the Covenant and in 1980, under Mr Fraser, ratified it. What has happened to the then Government's sense of propriety and sense of liberties since 1980? What has happened to its sense of international responsibility, to its sense of giving a lead to the rest of the world which, unfortunately, does not enjoy the sorts of liberties we enjoy here. Why should we, having brought this covenant to fruition, mainly under Liberal and National Party efforts, now turn our backs on the world? The reality is that we should not.

The Bill of Rights has been misinterpreted around the country. It sets out a minimum of rights. In fact, Senator Durack says that it does not set out enough rights and that other rights ought to be added to it. I cannot quite gather from what he said towards the end of his speech whether he was saying that this Bill of Rights is no good at all because it sets out rights or whether he is saying that it is no good at all because it does not set out enough rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is saying that he is self-contradictory and that is par for the course.

—That is so. I think we have to hear from the many Opposition speakers what the Opposition is saying. Is it saying that we should not have a right to peaceful assembly? Is it saying that there should be no freedom of association?
—Article 9.

—I thank Senator Tate. Are we saying that we should not have freedom to adopt a religion or a belief? What is the Opposition saying? Is the Opposition saying: `We agree with what is set out there but there ought to be more put in'. The Opposition has to decide on what it says. Article 9.3 provides that any person arrested or detained on a criminal charge has a right to be tried within a reasonable time. Do we disagree with that? Do we disagree with the right of a person to communicate with a lawyer? Do we disagree with the right to receive legal assistance? Indeed, as regards common law rights, the common law does not guarantee a person a right to have legal assistance at a trial.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to get on to another point on this matter. The Opposition talks about the common law. Who is the mother of common law? What is the origin of the common law? The common law comes from England. Let us just have a look at the situation in England. Without doubt, somebody will quote, in the context of this debate, the statement by Sir Harry Gibbs, the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia-

TALK.START.PARA: —They ought to have a look at what Lord Scarman in England said.

—I will tell honourable senators what Lord Scarman says. Senator Haines has no doubt read what Lord Scarman says. I quote Lord Scarman, when he talked about the English common law and its ability to protect the rights of everybody. He reached the conclusion that the common law `lacks a coherent basis of principle'. This is the great common law system, the traditions on which the Opposition is going to rely. This is a judge, a Law Lord in the House of Lords, the very peak of the common law.
—Pinnacle.
—Thank you, Senator Tate-the pinnacle of the common law system. In relation to the common law Lord Scarman states:

SPEECH.PARA: It lacks a coherent basis of principle upon which it can tackle the problems of human rights in a modern setting. To this extent the common law has failed. A new Bill of Rights-
A Bill of Rights! Here is the Law Lord suggesting a Bill of Rights-
. . . could establish guiding principles that would set standards for politicians, administrators and judges.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what we did with the Human Rights Commission.

—That reference, which Senator Durack no doubt knows but which I will repeat for him, comes from the ninth Wilfrid Fullager Memorial Lecture in 1980, and it is set out in the 1981 Modern Law Review at page 1, although the particular quotation comes from pages 4 and 5. But let us have a look at the mother of the common law system and what it has done. In 1950 it became a party to the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, which was signed in Rome in 1950. That sets out rights very similar-no doubt the honourable senator has looked at them-to those set out in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. So here we are. The European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms sets out rights very much as is done in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights-but 16 years beforehand. Not only did England do that, but the mother of our traditions was party to a European Human Rights Commission set up under the convention; and not only that but took part in the establishment of the European Court of Human Rights. Indeed, that Court has overruled English courts.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give honourable senators a couple of examples. I shall cite them. There is the Sunday Times v. the United Kingdom, 1979, 2 European Human Rights Reports, at page 245, and Maloney v. the United Kingdom, 1984, 7 European Human Rights Reports, at page 14, in which it was held that the way England dealt with the question of privacy certainly was not in conformity with the way that people who have an appetite for civil rights and liberties would like it to be dealt with. The European Court held the position allowed by the common law to be in breach of human rights. But we, a child of the English common law system, say: `No, even though the parent, the mother, has what is in effect a Bill of Rights, we are too good; we should not have that; we should reject it'. We say that we will not be like Canada, which has a human rights Bill, or like the United States. We will not be like that; we will go our own way.

Of course, there is then an attack on the notion of any sanction to enforce the Bill of Rights. The sorts of countries that have a Bill of Rights but do not have any enforcement provisions are, I hope, not the sorts of countries that Senator Durack and the Opposition would adopt, take example from, because perhaps the prime example of a country that has a written Bill of Rights without any enforcement provisions is Russia. Are we going to adopt, as might be suggested-not directly by Senator Durack, but certainly by the sorts of arguments he puts-a situation such as that which prevails in Russia, or will we have a Bill of Rights which vindicates our position as a nation in the world that is seeking, with other nations, to bring about at least some universal minimum of justice, liberty and decency? Are we going to face up to our responsibilities in those respects?

Let us make clear what the common law does do and does not do. The common law certainly does not guarantee the sorts of rights that are set out in this Bill. It does not guarantee a right to freedom of religion. It does not guarantee a right to participate in public life. It does not guarantee a right to peaceful assembly. It does not guarantee rights for children. It does not give people a right to vote. It does not do any of those things. In fact, the statement made by Sir Harry Gibbs to which I referred indicates just that, because the inference in what he said is that it is not the law, whether the common law or otherwise, that protects human rights but the character of the society in which we live. So let us make it clear right from the start of this debate that it is not the common law that ensures what we regard as our fundamental rights. I just want to add one quotation which, although not directly on the point, expresses fairly well what I have been saying about our international obligations and about our own profile. It is a quotation from Abraham Lincoln in his message to Congress in 1862. He said:
In giving freedom to the slave we assure freedom to the free-honourable alike in what we give and what we preserve.

This Bill of Rights, adopting the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, should be looked at in that light. That International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which has been so fiercely attacked here today, is a thing that gives freedom not to the `slave' of which Abraham Lincoln spoke but to those countries in which there are a host of modern slaves and in which people are systematically tortured. By doing that we assure freedom to the free. Doing that is an honourable thing-`alike in what we give and what we preserve'. Opposition senators will get up and castigate this Bill of Rights over the next few days. I simply ask every one of them-I will be interested to hear what they say-what they are going to do for the people tortured, no matter where in this world, or under what system. What will they do for the people who have the electricity applied to their sensitive parts, in places where people have torture and degradation heaped upon them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hazard a guess that in all the five years that I have been a member of this place I have never before run into so much misinformation being spread around the community about any piece of legislation as that which has been disseminated about the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bills which accompany it. The number of chicken littles who are running around this country claiming the sky will fall in if we pass this piece of legislation is extraordinary. Sadly, they are often masquerading as Christians and are behaving in a most un-christianlike manner, peddling lies and stirring up fear in the minds of ordinary, honest, reasonable people in the community. The letters that I have had from people who have been subject to this disinformation or misinformation campaign indicate the extent to which some people in the community will go to stop a piece of legislation going through. It is, I would suggest, a campaign that most totalitarian regimes would envy for its extent and success.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go into some of the concerns that have been expressed to me about this Bill, quite unnecessarily I might add, I think we need to look at its origin and just exactly what it does do as distinct from what some people think it will do. It results, of course, from the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and it is, in fact, a particularly weak piece of legislation. It follows not only the signing but also the ratification of that Covenant by the previous Fraser Government in 1980. It is not only Australia, of all Commonwealth or Western countries, which has signed and ratified this Covenant, despite the fact that the majority of letters that I get say things like: `It is based on the United Nations ICCPR which has been accepted by Warsaw Pact countries'-by the way, in the majority of letters it is spelt `Pack'-`and rejected by the UK and the USA'. Hence, they argue that it will lead to a totalitarian state.

I suggest that some kind soul incorporate in Hansard a copy of the signatories and the ratifiers of this Covenant because then people will see that not only has Australia signed and ratified it, but so has the United Kingdom, which in addition is a participator in and covered by the European Covenant, which I suggest is a much stronger covenant. Canada ratified the United Nations Covenant on 19 May 1976. Prior to doing that, in 1960 it implemented the articles of the Covenant in its own Bill of Rights and it did that in a legislative form. By 1982 the Canadians were sufficiently satisfied with the working of it to allow it to be incorporated into their own Constitution. To the best of my knowledge, so far Canada has not become either a communist or a totalitarian state, although, when my Secretary was on the phone trying to explain this to a lady who rang up in some concern the other day, she did not get terribly far. The lady stopped in her tracks as she was not aware of what Canada had done. She was only aware of the distortions that had been given to her. However, she was not to be outdone. She stopped, thought for a moment and then said: `But Canada is not as free as it used to be'.

A lot of these people really do not want to listen. For example, another senator, who I understand spoke at a very large meeting on this issue, put the points, went through the Article, pointed out that it was not going to lead to homosexual marriages under Article 13 and other bits and pieces that had been spread around the community, and when he had finished at the end of the meeting a man came up to him and said: `Senator, you have a wonderful way with words, but you did not fool me'. They do not want to know. They do not let facts get in the way of a good argument.

Then we have the information that the Bill of Rights is going to seep into the entire community, that somehow it is going to set neighbour against neighbour, individual against companies and it is going to get its little tendrils into all sorts of dreadful areas, including interfering with States' rights. Apart from the fact that I happen to believe-and my Party supports me in this-that it ought to cover the States, for a variety of reasons, in fact it is a particularly weak Bill in that it only offers to protect individual citizens against jackbooting bureaucracies. I think it is important that that piece of information goes out into the community. It is one of the reasons, for example, why the much maligned proposed Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, like a lot of other commissions, and tribunals and so on that we have in this country, does not allow legal representation. It is, of course, intended to balance the individual against the much bigger organisations of Federal Government departments. I leave it to the imagination of honourable senators to work out who would be able to afford better and more lawyers in a fight between an individual and the Department of Social Security, for example.

Even if it only covers Federal Government instrumentalities, this Bill goes some way to giving additional protection to ordinary individuals. Nevertheless, it is a concern of people who write and say that the Bill is to be administered by an appointed, as distinct from a democratically elected, body of people. I do not know what they think judges are, by the way, since most other pieces of legislation are interpreted by the courts which, of course, are made up of appointed bodies of people. Anyway, they are saying that it is to be administered by an appointed body of people with powers that exceed the normal processes of the law. They say it is a Star Chamber and an inquisitorial body. It has no appeal, they say, and can have closed hearings. It can call for documents and no legal representation is to be allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the Bill says.

—It certainly does. I suggest the same thing applies to things like the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the Repatriation Review Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. To argue that there is no appeal from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission ignores the fact that there is only one additional power given to HREOC under this legislation that does not already exist under the Liberal Government's Human Rights Commission, and that is the power to call compulsory conferences. It also ignores the fact, as I read the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, that in section 5 there is an appeal mechanism. To argue that this is some kind of inquisitorial Star Chamber that is going to stop people from doing what they want ignores a number of facts, including the fact that all it can possible do is report to the Minister and suggest that some dictatorial bureaucracy is stopped from doing what it wants. To argue that HREOC is some kind of totalitarian communist inspired organisation not only overlooks the facts, it overlooks the important correlation between that Commission and a number of other existing bodies we have in this country which are established specifically to protect the rights of individual citizens against organisations that are so large that under ordinary circumstances they would not have the proverbial ice cream's hope in hell of getting anywhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to one or two of the other misconceptions that are being spread around the community. I would like to pick up Senator Durack's comment about the fact that this Bill does not include the right to own property. That, of course, is because that is not covered in the Covenant, which he pointed out. We certainly would not have any particular objections to the Bill suffering, if I can use that word, a simple amendment to the effect that there is a right to own property.

There are large numbers of people in the community-and I include the Returned Services League in this-who believe that this Bill actually takes away a right to own property and that somehow we have had that right in this country, if not since its inception, since Federation. In fact, that is not the case. Neither at State level nor at Commonwealth level have we ever had the absolute right to own property. At the Commonwealth level, section 51, Part 31, I think it is, gives us the right to have the Federal Government pay either an individual or a State just compensation if it acquires your property, but at the State level not even that applies. To argue, as the RSL does, that this Bill will take away our right to own property is an absolute nonsense and I suggest that some of these people acquaint themselves with State and Federal Government constitutions. The point, however, is that, even if we do put into this Bill the right to own property, unless we also extend it to the States, it is not going to stop somebody like Mr Wran from coming up with another Coal Acquisition Act of 1981. Unless the States are covered by it we can put in any property rights we like and it will not stop Premiers and dictatorial parliaments from treading all over ordinary people.

I then come to the argument that there has been no time for discussion and examination of this Bill by the people, that it was rushed through the House of Representatives and passed in the dead of night, as if it was the first Bill, indeed, that was passed in either this Parliament or in any State parliament in the early hours of the morning and as if that necessarily makes it something sinister. Stupid, yes; sinister, no. Certainly we have had a Bill of Rights of some sort before the Federal Parliament since 1973. I would have thought that 12 years was long enough for 15 million people, or however many interested bodies there are among that 15 million people, to get to know what was in it.

The Bills have all been different. This has to be the weakest of them. Unfortunately, the people in the community who have caught up with the legislation have got only as far as Senator Evans's Bill which was a much more grandiose scheme to extend various rights to people. They write to me, unhappily quoting sections from Senator Evans's Bill, and are not aware or have not been made aware-I suggest that they have not been made aware deliberately by the people peddling these stories-that this Bill bears no more relation to Senator Evans's Bill than does the nature of the current Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) bear any relation to that of the previous Attorney-General. People are saying such things as: `This Bill will lead to homosexual marriages'. The first time that I saw this I thought: `My God, what have I missed in this legislation? People are writing to me saying that Article 13 will allow homosexual-they do not say encourage-marriages. I turned to Article 13. It is headed `Right to marry and to found a family'. It says:
Recognising that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society-
which again runs counter to the argument of all the people who say that the legislation is anti-family-
and is entitled to protection by society and the State-
(a) every man and woman of marriageable age has the right to marry a person of the opposite sex and to found a family.

Anybody who can tell me how that can be interpreted to allow homosexual marriages has a mind more devious than my own. Just to muddy the waters a trifle I suggest that it is possible under current law for two people whose interests are of the homosexual variety to be married anyway, providing they are of the opposite sex. This Bill allows nothing that is not currently available to whatever strange minds are operating in the community. Having finished--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they consummate the marriage?
—I do not really want to get into that sort of discussion. I do not have the time; nor is this chamber the appropriate place.
—They could, with difficulty.
—Be quiet, Senator Chipp.
—You are doing very well without my help.

—Thank you. We then get the argument that common law is sufficient for the protection of our rights. Let us go on from Lord Scarman for a moment. As Senator Cooney said, sooner or later we will have waved under our noses that famous piece of rhetoric from Sir Harry Gibbs which says:

SPEECH.PARA: If a society is tolerant and rational, it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

That overlooks the general point that we in this place do not make laws for when things are going right. Normal practice is to make laws for when things are going wrong or are likely to go wrong. Leaving that aside, Sir Harry needs to consider-following the comments of Senator Cooney about Lord Scarman-what the law lord said:
When times are normal-
and they very rarely are in the Senate-
and fear is not stalking the land, English law sturdily protects the freedom of the individual and respects human personality. But when times are abnormally alive with fear and prejudice-
I suggest that this definitely is one of those times-
the common law is at a disadvantage: it cannot resist the will, however frightened and prejudiced it may be, of Parliament.

We need to consider that. It is fine having legislation for when things go right. We really need legislation for when things go wrong. But even then the things that we think we have absolute right to, as with property rights, we do not necessarily have. Neither common law nor statute law, for example, provides us with full protection or gives us many of the rights that people such as those in the Returned Services League and others think we have.

There is a common belief in the community that we have the absolute right to legal representation at a trial. The McInnes case knocked that assumption fairly and squarely on the head. There is an argument that we have a juristic right to protest. I suggest that Campbell v. Samuels eliminated that idea for all time. As far as the guaranteed inalienable right to freedom of worship is concerned, I refer honourable senators to the Grace Bible Church case. Finally, when we talk about how valuable common law is as distinct from statute law, I refer honourable senators to that absurd Victorian case last year when a judge, who-for very good reason-suppressed his name as a consequence, ignored existing State legislation and went back to a 1609 British common law decision that allowed a man to violate and abuse his wife. Senator Durack talked about the fact that the Covenant was established several decades ago and therefore we need to reconsider. What on earth are we doing going back 380 years to a common law decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —They were the days.

—Oh, that has to go into Hansard, Senator. They might have been the days for some people; they are not the days now. It is quite inappropriate for this sort of thing to happen. I come back to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Some people say that if the Parliament passes this Bill it will transfer the power of interpretation of legislation from parliament, they say, to an unelected body-first to HREOC and secondly to the courts. I do not know what they think has been happening in this country but to the best of my knowledge parliament has never had the right to interpret legislation.
