Certainly we have tried on occasions-for example, through extrinsic aids to statutory interpretation and the odd Acts Interpretation Act. Who pays attention to them? I suggest that not many of the judges interpreting the Trade Practices Act have done so; they apply their own interpretations. They have turned their own minds to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament as an elected body, while it has the right to make laws, has never had the right to interpret them. We have never come up with a perfect piece of legislation, anyway, so there is always a role for courts and lawyers in settling exactly what is meant by legislation. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is no less an unelected body than the courts. Indeed, the Bill makes provision to allow judges to sit on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. It is not as if we were planning to leave the functions of the Commission to a clutch of people, brought in off the street, with no capacity to understand the legislation. People also write to me-I reiterate that they are ordinary, nice people in the community who have been evilly and unjustifiably misled by a number of people masquerading as moral, upright and Christian but are nothing of the sort-saying that this is a back door method of changing the Constitution, and that we ought not to pass it without a referendum. We do not have referendums to pass normal legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't alter the Constitution every day, either.

—We are not altering the Constitution, you silly person. We are passing legislation that will give ordinary people in the community some rights so that Federal government departments cannot trample over them. The legislation ought to be extended to States so that States and their bureaucracies cannot trample over them. We can alter the Constitution in this country only by a referendum. When the time comes for these rights to be incorporated in the Constitution a referendum is the only way to do it; so the honourable senator should not talk to me about this legislation changing the Constitution because, if he believes that it is, he is not fit to be in this place because he does not know the difference between a constitution and a piece of legislation. What a silly little person he is.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is by no means perfect. Senator Durack touched in his speech on some of those issues. I have indeed already covered the right to own property. As I have said, we will be perfectly happy to consider a simple amendment that incorporates the right to own property. The Opposition's amendment is a half-page amendment that goes right outside the rest of the Covenant, and is singularly inappropriate.

There is also a legitimate concern among Opposition parties and the community generally that, while there is a right to belong to an association, there is no additional right not to belong. Lawyers will tell us that the negative is incorporated in the positive and other sorts of legal things. My response to that is: `If that is the case, gentlemen, you will not mind if it is attached because it is not doing anything that you argue is not already there'. A simple statement that would allow people the right not only to belong to an association but also not to belong to it would find no problems with me or, I suggest, with my Party. The way that the Opposition wants to go about it, with an amendment that is extremely lengthy, is asking for trouble.

However, I also point out that, while countries have the right to reserve from Articles in the Covenant, problems arise when those countries then produce legislation including Articles which are not part of the Covenant. That will make the chances of a High Court challenge so much greater. The inclusion of the right to own property, and the fiddling about with the wording of the right to belong to an association to allow it to cover people who do not want to belong to an association, may well lead to a High Court challenge, but I think the issue is probably important enough to countenance that.

I think I have covered most of the other points. I want now to come to the main objection that we as a party have to this legislation-that the legislation does not apply to the States. This is particularly unfortunate when one considers Article 6. It seems wholly inappropriate for Australian newspapers to run indignant stories about rigging and unfair elections in the Philippines when we have the sort of situation that applies in Queensland. At least Marcos managed to get 46 per cent of the vote to force his way into Parliament. Queensland has a unicameral system-not even the protective measure of an upper House, however awkwardly elected that may be, as indeed it is in Western Australia-in which the National Party of Australia, by rigging the boundaries to the extent indeed that one chunk of an electorate is in the middle of another electorate and there is not even a little connecting link-and that Party does not even pretend that there is some reason for it-can get itself elected with 34 per cent of the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair go! What about the preferences?

—Terrific! I am perfectly happy to pick up that interjection. First of all, it is an indication that Senator Boswell thinks that a 39 per cent majority of first preference votes is okay to give a political party an absolute majority of seats in a parliament. Secondly, it indicates that he has not had a close look at the new boundaries in Queensland which drop that `appropriate' 39 per cent to what I consider a highly inappropriate 35 per cent of 34 per cent. So that we get it quite clear, Senator Boswell is quite happy to have a government elected when it gets only 39 per cent of the primary votes. I wonder then why we say the hysteria from the Liberal shadow Attorney-General in South Australia who complained that the Liberal Party might have to get 51 per cent of the vote before it got an absolute majority in the South Australian Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The various people on this side of the House in the Opposition parties ought to get their act together-I add that this is as good an act to get together on as any-and include the States under the system suggested by Senator Tate's Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That is a more than appropriate way of extending the scope of this legislation so that it really does apply some rights to individuals vis-a-vis State and Federal governments and departments. That Committee suggested that at the very least a displacement provision mechanism should apply, that is, that the Bill be amended-and we shall move in that way-so that the States are covered by the legislation with the option of opting out of all Articles but Article 6. Senator Boswell can have a little riot about that. Article 6 relates to fair and just elections-something, of course, with which Queenslanders are not familiar, and I can understand Senator Boswell's fear of the unfamiliar. However, all I can suggest is that the rest of us have fair and just elections. We do not have to rig boundaries. I say to Senator Boswell that there is nothing to be afraid of except that his Party might lose government, so we are looking at vested interests as well as fear of the unknown.

If I have any complaint at all about this Bill it is that it does not go far enough. In not going far enough, it may delude people into believing that they have rights that they actually do not have and, in so deluding people, it will perform a disservice rather than a service to the community generally. We will consider amendments to improve the Bill, the main one of which will be that relating to its application to the States. I look forward to enthusiastic support for that amendment from all people in this chamber who believe in freedom and democracy in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Australian Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill 1985, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill 1985, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985 and the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985. It is probably interesting to comment on who are the great majority of people out in the community who are crying for this legislation. Who are the people who have had their rights shattered, ruined and taken away from them? It is certainly not the Returned Services League. It is not any of the church groups. It is not the Law Council of Australia, because it has great reservations about the legislation. It is not the National Farmers Federation; it does not want it. I have not heard one person who does want it except those from the left wing of the Australian Labor Party--
—And the Democrats.

—And the Democrats. I include even Senator Tate. When I read his expose in the Australian I thought I was reading that he was not for the legislation. When I read it I thought: `I quite agree with Senator Tate because he does not want it'. Poor old Senator Cooney then gets sent in on a fast wicket every time and has to defend things that he does not want to do. He is pushed in because he is a barrister or a solicitor. He comes in like a good ALP soldier. He does not want to do it and his speech indicates that. He has no sympathy with the legislation and nor has Senator Tate. Of course, they throw a few sops to the left wing of the Labor Party and to the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at why the Democrats want to achieve what they call one vote one value-electoral justice. I can tell them that the best electoral justice Queensland will ever have is when the Democrats are removed from Queensland, I will concentrate on that in the next election. I will work at that, I promise, because 30 per cent of the Australian Democrats' senatorial vote comes from the bush. The last thing that rural Queenslanders want, on top of everything else that the Democrats have inflicted upon them, including animal welfare and a million other things, is a Bill or Rights. I will go to every radio station and every newspaper and will tell the rural people of Queensland that they are to get a Bill of Rights courtesy of the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will pay your expenses; how about that?

—I hope you do. What the Labor Party has never been able to achieve in the ballot boxes in Queensland, it is now trying to achieve by bringing in overriding legislation. Let us get a couple of things straight because Senator Chipp does not really understand preferential voting. I put it on the record that the National Party got 39 per cent of the vote and the Liberal Party 14 per cent. If we add those together it gives us 53 per cent of the people not wanting an Australian Labor Party Government. Only 44 per cent of the voters in Queensland supported the ALP. So 53 per cent did not want a bar of the Labor Party and 44 per cent did. Five per cent or 3 per cent of the voters, or something of that order, were misguided people who wanted the Australian Democrats. That is what preferential voting is all about, but those opposite do not even understand it. We have been attacked and abused by the Democrats and the Labor Party because they do not want to understand the situation. The Government can see the Bjelke-Petersen Government leading a resurgence of the conservative forces in Australia and, if it can get rid of him in some way, it will take the pressure off itself. So what members of the Government cannot achieve out in the States, because of Robin Gray and Joh Bjelke-Petersen, they are trying to achieve in this Parliament. I would like to read a statement from a book entitled The Government of Queensland because it is pertinent to this matter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Detailed examination of one distribution, Queensland for 1972, suggests that even close attention to the electoral map may fail to uncover adequate evidence of the gerrymander at work. This is not to say that the beast does not exist. It may lurk, like the yeti or the Tasmanian tiger, in the impenetrable thickets of thousands of polling booths. But for the moment it has defied capture. Detailed examination of Queensland in 1977 suggests the same conclusion.

That book was not written by Sir Robert Sparkes, Joh Bjelke-Petersen or Ron Boswell, it was written by the Australian Electoral Commissioner. He was no National Party plant. He is the most prominent authority on electoral matters in this country, and the Labor Party put him in that position. He is its Commissioner. I recommend that everyone opposite get this book from the library and study it because the 1977 boundaries are the boundaries on which the Queensland Government went to the people. Colin A. Hughes says that they were fair, that he could find no gerrymander. Let us put it to rest once and for all: The Queensland Government win because the majority of Queenslanders wanted a conservative government-53 per cent as against 44 per cent who wanted an ALP government. If the Labor Party wants to get into government in Queensland all it has to achieve is 50.1 per cent of the vote in 50.1 per cent of the seats. I wanted to put that to rest because I am sick and tired of being attacked by the Democrats, being attacked by Senator Gareth Evans, who is not here, and being attacked by everyone else.

What does this Bill of Rights and equal opportunity legislation do for us? Senator Chipp said that it would take the National Party 20 years to approve of this legislation. The National Party would not approve of it in one million years. It seeks to ruin the State parliaments of Australia. This Government was brought in on a promise to bring Australians together but, as I said in an interjection only a few minutes ago, it will put Australians against Australians. It will put Brian Burke against his own Party in Canberra; all the ALP Premiers will be fighting. It will be such an issue that it certainly will not bring Australians together. I would like to quote what the Law Council of Australia says about the legislation. It certainly does not support the National Party; it is bipartisan and has an equal number of supporters in the various political parties. The Law Council says:
There is no obvious limitation to the exercise of that discretion and the potential exists therefore for the discretion to be exercised according to political motives.

That is what the Law Council says about this legislation, and yet Government senators come in here and say that the people of Australia want it, they need it and their rights are being eroded. Australia is the freest country in the world. Every one of us in this chamber has spent hours talking to people who want to bring in friends and families, but they would not want to bring people here if we had no rights. This is the freest country in the world and yet the Labor Party, with the Democrats, is going to wreck everything that we believe in. It will put shock waves right through the whole legal system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the right of assembly in Queensland.

—I will tell the honour- able senator about the slavery and servitude that the Human Rights Commission said existed in Queensland following a quick investigation. The Government has put tremendous powers in the Human Rights Commission, but it has put out a shocking report. It did not even go to the Government on whose behalf it was investigating. What confidence can we have in a Commission that would act in such a way. Even Chris Hurford, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, says that he has lost confidence in the Human Rights Commission. I would not blame anyone for losing confidence in the Commission. It threw Mr Neil Brown out of its office; it did not give much consideration to his human rights. One of the first things that this Commission, formed at a cost to the Australian public of some $7m, did was run a pop concert, of all things. It was nothing more than a public relations campaign so that kids would give the Human Rights Commission some credibility. What a disgusting thing for a Human Rights Commission to do. I hope that one of the Government speakers picks that up when addressing this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never seen eroded any rights to marry and found a family. I have never seen rights to freedom of thought and conscience eroded. The right of participation in public life has never been eroded. Why do we need a Human Rights Bill? We do not need such a Bill. No one in Australia wants to have a bar of it, except for the crazy reason, as I have suggested to the Senate, that what the Labor Party cannot win in the ballot boxes it is now trying to take over by way of Commonwealth legislation.

We should examine some of the powers that the Human Rights Commission has been given. First, it can investigate any Acts of any State parliament. If that is not a raping of State rights, I do not know what is. No longer can a State bring down legislation, no longer can a court put legislation into effect, unless it conforms to the Human Rights Bill we are debating today. Any State legislation can be referred to a Federal court. This is the beginning of the end for States rights and I say emphatically that when we are returned to government in three years, or whenever the next election is, this will be the first piece of legislation to head for the rubbish dump.

The poor, unsuspecting person who normally votes according to his hip pocket nerve, who does not usually take into account legislation that flows through this place but just considers whether financially he will be better or worse off and casts his vote accordingly, has to watch out. He is the person who is having his Constitution stolen off him and removed from him. He does not understand it. I can tell the people of Australia that they will have to wake up. Their rights are being eroded and their Constitution is being moved away from them. If a Bill of Rights is required and if there is a great demand for a Bill of Rights we should go to a referendum. Let us put it before the people. Let us go out and debate it on the highways and the byways. We will give our side of the story, members of the Australian Labor Party will give theirs, the Australian Democrats will give theirs and we will let the people decide. It is our Constitution. The people out there own the Constitution. This Constitution does not belong to eight Democrats and so many Labor senators. It belongs to the people of Australia and it should only be changed by the vote of the people of Australia.

Tremendous powers are being given to the Human Rights Commission by this legislation. There are tremendous changes to the judicial system. The Attorney-General can ask the Human Rights Commission to go out and investigate any matter in a State. The Attorney-General has the right, under this legislation, to tell the Human Rights Commission to go out and investigate any Act of Parliament in Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia or Victoria. This can be used politically. It can be used against a government of a persuasion opposite to that of the Attorney-General. That is what this Government has done. It has elected a Human Rights Commission which can act as a court to investigate any Act of any State.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there is no appeal.

—And there is no appeal. If a person is brought before that court that person cannot have any legal representation. That person can be fined or imprisoned. Senator Cooney, who is a legal representative, stood up in this chamber and had the audacity to support this type of legislation. He should be absolutely ashamed of himself. That is what has happened. This Government has set up this Human Rights Commission which can act as a court and it can be politically motivated. It does not have to be elected. It is not politically free. It can get its riding instructions from the Federal Attorney-General. If Senator Cooney does not think that that is a breach of the Constitution and if anyone in the Senate has the temerity to stand up and say `We are not altering the Constitution', we should be charitable and say that he just does not understand the legislation or he does not want to understand it.

SPEECH.PARA: What Senator Durack has said in his speech on the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights Commission is true. The Government has set up a court. That court can be politically motivated. It can interfere in every State not only with State Acts but also with local government Acts. Nothing sacred is left. If there is a chance of a State court not abiding by the Bill of Rights that case can be transferred to a Federal court. If I am wrong I would like one of the solicitors in this Parliament-there are plenty of them-to get up and tell me I am wrong because I have read this legislation thoroughly. I believe that I understand it thoroughly and I believe that I have reached the right conclusions on it. These Bills are terrible Bills. No one wants them. I do not believe that any of the Labor Party's State colleagues would want the legislation. I do not believe that any organisation, whether it be a church organisation or a Returned Services League-any organisation-wants these Bills. Yet they are being inflicted on the Australian people without the Government going out and putting it to a referendum. If that is the way the Government wants to play the game we will play it hard too.

I believe that this is the biggest political issue at the moment. It passes the Government's promise, which it will not keep, to reduce fuel prices. All these things can be returned and the economy can be lifted when we get back into government. But this constitutional change without a referendum is base and it should never be allowed to go through. I will have great pleasure in voting against the legislation and I will be opposing it every chance that I get.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to object to the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill and the associated Bills. I can remember when I first became a member of parliament that the human rights issue was a hot goer. The then senator Lionel Murphy had charge of the issue at the time. Succeeding governments have all tried to bring in human rights Bills of one sort or another. Every time it has happened it has generated enormous public hostility and it has made me wonder why on earth governments do this sort of thing. If we analyse it quietly and critically we can see why they are doing it. It is in order to grab power. That is what the whole thing is all about. These Bills have been altered, twisted, turned, re-presented, rejected and brought back again. The only reason for it is that governments know that, by the implication of the Bills, they will have an enormous increase in their powers. In this case the Government is seeking powers which are really outside the political and constitutional process. In my view, no government should clothe itself with powers that are not vouchsafed to it under its Constitution and that is what is happening with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things I have noticed with these repeated human rights-type Bills is that every time governments bring them in they neglect to define what is meant by `a right'. I suppose we could say that there are two sorts of rights. There are human rights and there are legal rights. But when governments are talking about human rights they want to give people the rights to things such as food, clothing, shelter, jobs, health and social welfare and they want to call them rights. Let us suppose that we gave everyone the right to, say, shoes. Let us suppose that the Government felt in its heart that shoes were very important for people and everybody had to have shoes. Because of the difficult nature of supplying shoes to people only the Government could do it and people should not be left with the responsibility of providing their own shoes. There have to be shoes for children who grow up and change sizes all the time. There have to be shoes for girls and boys. When they grow up and are adults they have to have different sized shoes. Everybody has different sorts of feet and there are different sorts of fashions. This enormous and complicated problem cannot be left to the people with the massive distribution problem that it would have. If the Government took on the supply and distribution of shoes we would have something like Mao Tse-tung's China had where everybody got around in little black slippers and we would have the usual sort of mess.

The point I am trying to make is that I do not think any government should give anybody the right to a thing. Rights, particularly human rights, exist around us all the time. We have them. They are moral principles by which we behave towards one another. If we, as a government, give people the right to a thing that means that everybody else in the community has to supply that thing for them. It gives the rest of the people a responsibility to supply the others. I think the impossibility of doing that sort of thing is immediately apparent. What is also immediately apparent is the enormous increase that would occur in governments' power.

One of the important points I see about the Government defining these rights is that it is not governments that give people rights. I think it is the people who give governments rights. There has been a constant struggle over the years for people to curtail the enormous powers of governments. After governments have been in power for a while they try to accumulate more and more power to themselves and the people have a constant battle on their hands to keep out of the hands of governments powers that they did not vouchsafe to them in the Constitution.

Almost every law we pass in this Parliament takes away the rights of somebody and gives them to somebody else. That is true of almost every Bill we pass. It is the people who give governments rights, not the other way around with the government defining people's rights. If we admit that the government has the right to define our rights, then we admit that we are giving the government the right to take away our rights. In other words, the government gets an immediate expansion in its rights. One difficulty is that anything that is not defined as a right is automatically assumed to be not one's right. So governments expand their powers over people yet again.

We are forgetting the lessons of history and the interminable struggle for power between people and government. One has only to look at all the great revolutions in history, civil wars and so on, to see that they have been over human rights. Britain had a blood-curdling civil war between the Parliament and the people. Relative fought relative and the war continued for years. Parliament won the battle and the king wound up getting beheaded. That was over the powers of the king versus the Parliament. The United States of America had its war of independence. The cry there was: No taxation without representation. It also had a civil war and that, too, was over civil rights involving the issue of slavery. France had a revolution which wiped out the aristocracy. The cry in that revolution was `Liberty, equality, fraternity'. Russia and China have also had great revolutions with great loss of life-all to get rid of autocratic and aristocratic governments. All those civil wars and revolutions have been aimed at getting rid of aristocratic and autocratic governments. In other words, the power of government had become intolerable to people and the people fought it off.

The rise of the great democracies in recent years has featured the curtailment of government powers. In all countries that have constitutions restriction of government power has been the great feature. The founding fathers who wrote our Constitution were well aware of the dangers of big government. The Constitution they wrote was of such form that nobody could ever take over our government here in Australia. In fact, it led to the development of our three-tier form of government involving State, Federal and local government, with the devolution of powers among the three. The fact is that while the Queen remains head of the government, head of our great institutions, such as the judiciary, the defence forces, the Parliament, nobody else can be the head. This is why the Australian Labor Party is always trying to denigrate the role of the monarchy; the Australian Labor Party does not like the thought of having somebody there who cannot be replaced.

In this debate I have heard people speaking of freedom, but as with rights they have not defined what freedom is. It is a difficult word to define. I suppose it is like love, which is also hard to define because there are many sorts of it. There can be brotherly love, sisterly love, the love of a mother for a daughter, a father for a son, the love of a man for a woman. There are many different sorts of love just as there are many different sorts of freedom. For example, a Russian would have a different idea of freedom from a United States citizen. An Eskimo would have a different idea of freedom from an Indian. A European would have a different idea of freedom from an Australian. An Arab would have a different idea of freedom from, say, a Bantu. So they are all different. The men who wrote those undying words in the American Declaration of Independence-that all men are created equal and endowed by their creator with certain inalienable rights and among these rights is the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness-were slave owners. So they had a different perspective from that which is usually attributed to them. Even George Washington, the founding father of the Republic, was a slave owner. He had a different idea, a different perspective too.

Let us look at the different ways citizens of various countries and different regimes have established their rights over the years. It is instructive to look at how human rights are handled in the Soviet Union. Over there they have a Bill of Rights and give people the right to think their own thoughts, meet and speak in the streets and the right to this and to that. But it is said there that one has the right to each of those things provided one does not break any law. Then of course the Soviet authorities can pass a law that effectively robs all its citizens of their rights. That is one way people should not be getting human rights here in Australia. On the other hand, the USA has a Bill of Rights and defines the people's rights as the right to freedom of speech, the right to bear arms, the right to this and the right to that. But the Americans differ from the Russians because they say that no law shall be passed to infringe any of those rights. That is a better system, and if one looks at what has happened in the United States one sees that it is bound up with interminable litigation. Every time anyone has any trouble with anything there are court cases that go on for ever, and I understand that applies also to plea bargaining. That also is just not the Australian way.

The Australian way on the other hand, and the way I prefer of course, is as has been discussed here-by the development of the common law which has grown up over some 2,000 years of precedent. It has been associated with the development of parliamentary democracy, the development of a free press and an independent judiciary. In other words, there is a whole web of circumstances that secure and guarantee our rights. This is why the immediate public hostility that occurs is manifested whenever Bills of this sort are brought before the people. People in Australia realise that they have no fear of their rights being infringed.

There has been a lot of talk about rights of people in Queensland being infringed and our electoral system and street marches have been instanced. Well, street marches may have been necessary and useful in the days of the French revolution, but nowadays anyone who is any kind of a dissident and who has a problem can get any amount of publicity. Indeed it is easier to get publicity if one is a dissident than if one is part of the majority. The people of Queensland have shown again and again that they have no fear of their laws up there. They have not turned against their government up there, which they would do the minute they felt their rights were being infringed. So the reason that these human right Bills are generating public hostility is that the people know that they have their own rights, do not want them curtailed and do not feel they are in any danger, except danger from the government because government can only take rights away from people; they cannot give people rights.

It has also been said in this debate that the right to own property has been left out of the legislation as also has the right not to join a trade union. I agree that they are great omissions from the Bill. They were left out, I understand, at the request of the Soviet Union who would not ratify the document unless those conditions were taken out. Lastly, there is another way in which people are given rights. I have mentioned the Soviet Union way, the United States way, and the common law way, but now we have the United Nations way and the use of treaty power. That is precisely what is happening with these Bills. As has always been the case, they ratify various international covenants on civil and political rights against various forms of discrimination.

The United Nations consists of about 160 nations, of which only about a dozen could be classified as democracies. That counts the Philippines, which has just had an horrendous election, India and similar countries-only a dozen countries one could count in any way as being forms of democracy. The rest of them are totalitarian states, dictatorships, despotic or military regimes. They are all run in ways in which we would find completely abhorrent and could not stand in our administration. Yet all those nations sit in the UN cranking out different covenants, conventions and charters which contain clauses, terms and conditions which are completely inapplicable to Australia, although they all sound very good. I do not know why our Government would want to ratify those sorts of agreements for implementation in Australia unless, of course, its members want to big note themselves in front of the Third World countries and strut the world stage as if they are more enlightened members of government. By doing that and bringing in such Bills into Australia they are subjecting the people to enormous government control while they walk around saying that they are enlightened and are bringing freedom to the people. They are doing it in this way to try to bypass the people altogether and avoid the constitutional process. At the very least, as has been mentioned previously in the debate, the matter should be submitted to a referendum. The Bills were rammed through the House of Representatives, despite claims to the contrary made by the Australian Democrats. A time limit was put on the debate. Certainly, debate has gone on previously on different versions of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually it has not been debated previously. It has been on the Notice Paper.

—It has been on the Notice Paper, but the Government has always pulled it off because it has been too hot a potato to handle. It is now being presented to the Senate. I am sure that it has happened only because the Government, somehow or other, has secured the support of the Democrats. The Democrats have no members at all in the House of Representatives. They represent only about 8 per cent of the people, yet by wielding that 8 per cent of power-the balance of power in the Senate-they are responsible for inflicting these Bills on the Australian people. I, too, will go out and make sure that everybody in Australia knows that it is by courtesy of the Democrats that these fearsome Bills have been passed. I, too, regard this legislation as perhaps the most important legislation to be passed through the Parliament because it deals with human rights, our rights.

SPEECH.PARA: After all, that is why we invented government in the first place-to secure our rights. we have always been aware that it is the power of government that is the danger, so we invented our Constitution and rules by which governments should operate. Over centuries, governments have always tired to increase and embellish their powers, which is exactly what the Government is doing now and exactly why the National Party opposes the Government completely. When we eventually get to government, if ever we get enough say, these Bills will be the first Bills consigned to the trash can of history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the series of Bills before us, of which the main Bill is the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985. The remaining Bills, including the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill 1985, are ancillary to it and consequential upon it. I say at the outset that I oppose the package of Bills in its entirety for reasons which I will give. They are not the same reasons as the reasons of many people who have written to me and, I suppose, of many of the honourable senators who will speak in this chamber. However, I believe that my reasons why this package should not be passed are salient.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say in the first place that I am appalled by the degree of public controversy, misconception and ignorance which this debate has engendered. It is a sad day for Australia, a country not comparable with Canada which has been able to agree upon a Charter which it has had as legislation for 21 years, which it has now put into its Constitution and on which there was a reasonable unity and agreement between the parties. Clearly, that situation does not now exist in Australia. whatever bipartisanship we had on human rights-we had a considerable amount in the 1970s-has faded away. Now is clearly not the time to try to pass such a controversial legislation as the Bill of Rights Bill.

First, I want to get rid of some of the misconceptions about which I do not agree about the Bill. I take just one typical example. All of us have received dozens and dozens of letters, many of them in much the same form, and covering generally the same five points. Clearly, there is a very carefully organised campaign against the Bill. Unfortunately, in my opinion, much of it is misdirected. I shall quote from a letter I received from the Cross Roads Christian Fellowship organisation. Many of the most extraordinary claims are made by members of religious organisations. I am surprised that they have not read further before writing.

The Senate had an investigation of the matter carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We presented an exposure report before Christmas. The idea of the Committee was to present a document which would clear the air and remove some of the misconceptions. Its aim was not to make recommendations but to float various possibilities in regard to the general idea of the Bill of Rights. It appears that that document has hardly been read. The letters we have received show no cognisance whatsoever of the matters raised in that report. I find that deplorable. I shall run briefly through this letter from Cross Roads, which is typical of the literature we have received. The letter registers a protest against the proposed Bill and gives these reasons:
`1. Because of the way it adversely affects the areas of great importance to my liberty and freedom this legislation should not have been so hastily passed through the House of Representatives.'

That is one point that I think is justified. The handling of the Bill by the Government has been deplorable. First, the Government had the Bill which Senator Evans held back from public scrutiny. The result was that people thought that the Bill was much worse than it might have been. That was a very foolish action. The Bill should have been floated and made available for people to see and discuss. The later Bill, the Bowen Bill, that we are now discussing, is what I would call a Clayton's Bill of Rights. If one has to have a Bill of Rights and one does not really want to have one, one has a Clayton's Bill of Rights. That is rather an infringement and a shame, because Clayton's is a good drink, but a Clayton's Bill of Rights this Bill clearly is. It is an amendment on an amendment. It contains all the worst features of amendments and, as I will demonstrate later, contains matters which I think are unconstitutional.

The criticism that the haste of the Bill's passage has led to further misconceptions and encouraged people to think the Bill is very extraordinary is one criticism with which I agree. The second reason stated in the Cross Roads letter for its protest at the proposed Bill is as follows:

This legislation is based on the United Nations International Covenant on civil and Political Rights, was accepted by the Warsaw Pact countries, but rejected by such nations as the United States of America and Great Britain.

That is a colossally stupid series of remarks. The legislation certainly deals with areas of great importance and is based on the International Covenant. However, that Covenant was not proposed only by the Warsaw Pact countries. It was signed in 1966 when the Western powers had control of the General Assembly. We have ratified the Covenant. We signed it under the Menzies Government and ratified it under the Fraser Government. We have brought into effect the Human Rights Commission, which I regard as a very worthwhile institution in this country. These things were done at the initiative of the Western powers when they had control of the United Nations. So it is absurd to say that the fact that some communist countries have signed the Covenant and, very disgracefully, have not carried it out, in any way detracts from it. Moreover, it is ridiculous to say that the covenant's implementation is rejected by such nations as the United States of America and Great Britain. Great Britain, for example, has appeared often before the European Court of Human Rights, which operates under a convention very similar to the international convention. The British Government, the home of `common law', has in the last 10 years constantly been dealt with by that court and as a result has had to change its laws. It had to change its laws in relation to the treatment of prisoners in Northern Ireland gaols. Also in regard to the thalidomide case and other cases where the British law was not adequate, it has obeyed strictly the interpretations which the European Court of Justice has placed on it. So it is absurd to talk about Britain's not signing the covenant, because it is certainly affected by a European one just the same.

The United States is the home of a Bill of Rights. I am not a strong supporter of a Bill of Rights, but unquestionably there has been a Bill of Rights in the United States for nearly 200 years. One of the problems is that it has been so interpreted at various times that one never knows exactly what it means or whether this was the intention of its organisers. Because United States governments have not been able to get a high enough majority in the Senate-I think a three-quarters majority is required-they have never adopted the international covenant. Nonetheless, the United States has a Bill of Rights, and it has some of the defects which I will refer to later.

The third objection is a piece of gobbledegook about our Constitution presently stating `whereas we the people give you the Government these rights' and limiting the rights and powers of government. It has been said that this situation has been reversed in the Bill of Rights because the Government will give the people the rights. I do not think there is anything in this point, but the fact is that a government has some powers to define rights and to enforce them. Of course, we are subject to Federal constitution which is one of the real problems which this Bill has to face.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have not given us a reason for that. You just say that you don't think it is an important point. I think it is an important point.

—I do not think so. Our Constitution was made by the British Parliament and originally was passed by the Australian people. The Bill of Rights and the Human Rights Commission are constituted by an Act of Parliament. It does not alter the Constitution in any way. I do not think anything can be made out of that point.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth objection is that this proposed Bill of Rights gives the power of interpretation to the courts-an unelected body of people-and takes it from the Parliament, which is democratically elected by the people of the country. I have great reservations about a Bill of Rights and how it may be interpreted by judges with conservative backgrounds and often a very restricted knowledge of the reality of life. However, I do not find the fact that the courts are not elected by the people to be objectionable. We are always ready, and have been since 1901, to see Acts of this Parliament overturned by unelected judges of the High Court of Australia. We recognise that and accept it. Many of the people who have complained to me are only too glad that a number of the Acts of the Australian Parliament and Acts of State parliaments have been found to be in breach of the Constitution and have been removed. If honourable senators believe, as I do, in a general division of power between the Executive, the judiciary and the legislature and believe that is under some challenge today, they should not be so worried by the fact that judges are unelected. Judges are therefore not affected by party politics; they are, to some extent, independent. If we believe in the rule of law and the judiciary, we accept that fact.

The fifth objection is that the Human Rights Commission-another unelected body of the people-will administer the Bill of Rights, this Commission having powers outside and not subject to the normal processes of law, with no appeal, closed hearings and no legal representation. I am not going to go into that matter in any detail because it is not relevant to this Bill. However, one would never guess that from the correspondence one receives. The Human Rights Commission was set up under the Fraser Government in 1980. It will conclude, unless we do something, at the end of this year; and that is an important aspect. Nonetheless, the powers which it is given under this Bill are very similar to those which it has now. They would be extended in some respects but not by very much. The idea of such a body that does not use legal representation and all legal facilities is quite usual. We have applied this in many other areas. It is an administrative system of protecting rights. One hears objections to this, but if honourable senators read Senator Durack's admirable speech in support of the Human Rights Commission in 1979 they will find that it was accepted on all sides that we would have a body which was not a court but which carried out investigations.

Of course, we must bear in mind that there has now proved to be some difference in the Government's proposals. It has been suggested, quite sensibly by some, including Mr Peter Bailey, the Deputy Chairman of the Commission, that there is some inconsistency in giving the Human Rights Commission the powers to deal with education and conciliation and also a power of adjudication and determination. He suggested those powers could be moved to the Federal Court of Australia. We are not in a position to criticise the Human Rights Commission for trying to make the best of those powers. If we put them together and they prove to be unworkable, we should change them. It is up to us. Moreover, the people on the Human Rights Commission were appointed by the Fraser Government. From Dame Roma Mitchell down they have done a mighty fine job. There have been some 10,000 applicants. The Commission has done jobs which would never have been done by any committee of this Parliament. The derogation of that work in the public mind in the last few months or so is quite disgraceful and should be stopped.

That is not the point of this Bill. This legislation, which includes a Human Rights Commission and an Equal Opportunity Commission, is designed to change in the way the Government tried to change the Commission before the last election. The Opposition was quite opposed to that proposal because the Government was removing the part time commissioners, the people who represented various interests-the disabled, the migrants and the Aborigines-which would have left the control of the Commission entirely in the hands of bureaucrats. Senator Durack issued a statement then. We were ready to oppose that Bill but it was not introduced. There is a little more in this Bill because it is attached to the Bill of Rights, but basically it has the same powers as the existing Commission.

The confusion by the people who criticise the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights Commission-I refer to people who have written letters-should be put aside and we should look at the proposals themselves. We realise that we have international obligations which, as I said, go back to 1966 and which we have tried to comply with by creating the Human Rights Commission. That was an administrative method of dealing with the implementation of the covenant. The Government is now suggesting that we should have a system of judicial enforcement. I am not at all sure that that at any stage it is necessarily the desirable way to go; I am certain it is not a desirable time to push it forward at the moment.

People argue that we do not need to do anything about human rights because we have a wonderful country. That is all very well but the fact is that our country is a leader in the world of human rights. We must show that we apply the same principles to our internal affairs.

Undoubtedly, there are problems of great importance in Australia, not the least of which was mentioned this morning-the state of electoral laws. If we do not have the basic, proper democratic government we will be in a great deal of trouble. There are problems in Australia. At present we are not covered by the existing remedy. For example, people say that we have a Constitution and that it provides all we need. If one looks at such things in the Constitution as what might be called `Bill of Rights' provisions-there are a few of them but they are rather sporadic-one sees that, except in one case, they relate only to the Commonwealth Parliament and they restrict it in its actions. The States can do what they like. When one talks about just terms and the acquisition of property it is highly desirable that the States' powers should be restricted too. In my opinion this cannot be done under the powers of this Bill. Unfortunately, we have never exercised this power in years gone by when we Liberals had control of States and could have seen that they imposed these terms on themselves. However, they have not done so. We must recognise that the Constitution at the moment provides for the Commonwealth, largely, to be restricted, so that it cannot impose itself as regards human rights. A Government in a State, provided that it gets a majority every four years or whatever the period is, can be a dictator. The problem there is that the Constitution is not good enough by itself to cover human rights.

It is said that the common law is the magic thread. The common law has done a number of useful things in creating, particularly in the legal area, in the area of trials, some of the facilities which are available to people and which make for our freedom. But it has also had to be forced. People do not seem to understand that the common law is judge-made law. It is not the law which Parliament makes. In fact, Parliament has had to intervene to overcome deficiencies in the common law. Let us take, for example, the question of slavery. Slavery was not abolished by judges of the courts. The judges of the eighteenth century were busy protecting the interests of slave owners. It was Wilberforce and others in Parliament who managed to overcome this. So the common law has been very much a minor aspect in this matter. It has done some good things, but it does not protect us. This morning examples were given. I heard Senator Haines mention a number of examples where the common law-the judges' decisions-has been very restrictive, in some respects, of human rights.

Parliament also is not the protector. Let us not mistake that. We know that this Parliament is busy with lots of things. We know that we have some committees which look into civil liberties aspects of some of our legislation. But could the Parliament have had a committee which could have handled the 10,000 applications which the Human Rights Commission has dealt with in the last few years? No, it is obviously not good enough to say that Parliament will do this, because members of parliament are restricted very much by their party loyalties and very often things are not done, and not recognised, and the individual rights of citizens are not sufficiently protected. They are to some extent; questions are asked and actions are taken in Parliament, but they are by no means good enough.

The Bill, I have said, is a weak Bill. I do not hold the views of those who claim that it is some sort of social engineering. I do not know what that means; but they say that it is doing that. It is, as I say, a Clayton's Bill: If one does not want to have a Bill but feels one ought to have one, one gets this sort of Bill. The fact that it does not cover any actions in regard to State laws means that we are in a difficult position because, undoubtedly, many of the breaches take place in the States. In my view, the present rights of the Human Rights Commission do cover, though indirectly, the right to look into State laws, to compare them in making recommendations about Federal laws. It is rather indirect and it is rarely used. It may be distasteful but, undoubtedly, if we are to have a law which is effective, the Commission must also be able to look into State laws.

I come to the next and major point in this matter. In my belief, the Bills, as they stand, are unconstitutional and will meet their Waterloo in the High Court of Australia. We may go through this whole stressful position of passing a Bill only to find that it goes by the board. I base this partially on my own views and also on views expressed in a very full document by the Law Council of Australia which says, after saying that the object of the draft is to give effect to certain provisions of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights:
As has been noted above, the Bill also includes provisions of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other similar documents. This may lead to problems of constitutional validity.

That is one point. The Bill is called elsewhere a collage. It is a collection of different international covenants, and it therefore might not cover the situation. Further on in this document, the Law Council speaks of the redrafting which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has done of the various terms of the International Covenant. He says that he is doing this for more presentational reasons, and so forth; but I think that the action has been disastrous. The Law Council says:

The explanatory memorandum seeks to justify the technique in the Bill as being `inconsistent with the Australian attempt to produce an inspirational charter of rights in a simple declaratory style'. The Law Council believes that the result is unsatisfactory and it is preferable to tailor limitations to the specific needs of the right which has been guaranteed in the same way as the Covenant, particular provisions in the way which it requires.

I should give one example; there are many examples that could be given. What I am contending is that the rights which are set out in this Bill are not the rights which can only be justified under the Covenant. If we do not have such justification, they cannot be taken. In regard to the rights which are set out, one which is highly applicable and interesting is the right in Article 10 of the Bill on peaceful assembly. Honourable senators will recall that what the Bill does is to say, just in simple words, that every person has the right of peaceful assembly. Instead of having specific limitations put on these rights, as the Covenant has, Article 3 is a general one which covers them all:
The rights and freedoms set out in this Bill of Rights are subject only to such reasonable limitations prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.

What on earth does that mean? How wide is it? A judge might think that something is quite justified, but it may not be at all. If one looks at the International Covenant, on the other hand, one will see that specific things are said there about the rights to such things as public safety, public order and so forth. Specific things are set out in this and other covenants which limit the right. So, by sleight of hand, the Attorney- General has changed the nature of the Covenant altogether. That is only one reason why the Bill may well be unconstitutional.

The second reason is that Article 50 of the Covenant states that it must apply to all parts of Federal states without any limitations or exceptions. This Bill does not cover the States at all; it has excluded them. In fact, if one looks at one of the documents-I think it is the explanatory memorandum, section 15-one finds discussion of how it applies to States. This was so late in being taken out of the Bill that it was left in the explanatory memorandum. The fact is that if the States are taken out, it cannot cover all parts of Federal states. In my opinion, for this and for other reasons, it is likely that, as it stands, the Bill will prove to be unconstitutional. All this waste of energy and time and the stirring up of ignorance and malice and so forth will be for nothing.

The fact is that this is one of the problems which we have. We have a Bill here which may well fall by the board. I have objection, too, to amendments which the Opposition is moving to add things to the terms of the Bill, particularly in relation to the rights which are being created. I have already referred to the one in regard to just terms. That is very desirable, but I do not think for one moment it can possibly be justified under the terms of the Covenant. The right in regard to not joining trade unions is also an excellent idea and should be implemented, but that cannot be done. If we do these things, if we move into the State powers in this way, they have to be justified under the Constitution, and I cannot see, therefore, how these amendments help the position at all. If they were designed to have the effect of making the situation more unconstitutional, I do not think that is the right way to go about it. I think that the Bill should stand or fall as it is. I hope it will fall at this stage, because I think it would be foolish to carry on with it in the way it is going.

There is a great danger in the enforcement of human rights in terms of this Bill if it is carried. If the Bill is carried and it becomes a matter of long litigation in the High Court, what happens to the Commissioners for Race Relations and Sex Discrimination? In December, I asked them at a conference, what would happen if the Human Rights Commission disappears, because it would disappear at the end of this year. I asked: `How are you affected? Will you be cut off at the socks?' The reply was: `Yes, we will be cut off at the socks' and therefore what we achieved in the 1970s will be destroyed if this Bill goes on in this way'.

I believe that there are great difficulties in the interpretation of a Bill of Rights. I have had reason to read recently a book called The Great Chill by Eve Powell, a most alarming book on what is happening to human rights in the United States. The Americans have not only an extensive Bill of Rights but also the First Amendment, which protects freedom of speech. Yet, if one takes the case of the man named Snepp, who was denied the right to say anything after he left the Public Service, inroads are being made by the courts in the area of what some would regard as the protection of rights under the Bill of Rights. That has been going on where there is a Bill of Rights. I think one is left in the hands of the courts and how they interpret these provisions. One does not know for years, until someone challenges them, what the restrictions on governments will be.

I believe that our reputation as a country depends on how we handle civil rights. I believe that at present we are in the position where, unfortunately, there is no adult discussion on this, whereas the Canadians have managed that. In my opinion we should keep the Human Rights Commission for another five years. We should amend it, we should add State commissioners to it and we should alter some of its terms so that there are not the conflicts I have spoken of. I do not think we should embark at the moment on this particularly weak and useless document. What is being done by Australia is probably, unhappily, going to be to our discredit. Australia has a good reputation abroad. We have stood strongly for human rights. In this country we have weaknesses. I do not hide them and I never have. They are a matter of great worry. I think that we should be doing our best to interpret and to carry out the International Covenant.

We have an obligation to do that and under the Fraser Government we agreed to do that. I think we should continue to do that. However, our reputation stands to be damaged by introducing a Bill of Rights which is defective and we should not try to foist that on people at this stage.

Therefore, I oppose the Bills as they stand. I will not vote for some of the amendments, because I do not think they really add one iota to the discussion. I believe that the Government should take cognisance of the fact that, by pursuing this dangerous course, it might jeopardise the valuable achievements of the 1970s. The Government should think again about this course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today we are debating a very important package of human rights Bills. Its importance is demonstrated by the great volume of correspondence it has generated and by the 30 or so speakers participating in this debate. Any legislation dealing with the rights of individuals, particularly against governments, is of fundamental concern to the people of Australia. The coalition rejects the package of human rights Bills. If the Bills are passed, we will propose amendments; but we also will seek to repeal this legislation when re-elected to government. The coalition's opposition to the Bills is quite genuine. We wish to put three simple propositions: Firstly, a Bill of Rights is not necessary to protect rights; secondly, a Bill of Rights is not sufficient to protect rights; and, thirdly, this Bill of Rights, as presented, will simply serve as a political weapon for the Federal Government to use to attack State governments of different persuasion. We have already seen embryonic attempts to do this by the Human Rights Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental question to ask about this legislation is why the Government has introduced this Bill of Rights at this time. Is it because a Bill of Rights is necessary to protect our rights? Surely not. There has been no public pressure for this Bill. In fact, the overwhelming public response to it from very respectable quarters, as well as from the fringes, to which Senator Haines and Senator Gareth Evans referred in Question Time the other day, has been entirely negative, and for some good reasons. I have not received one letter, and I presume neither have most other senators, supporting the Bill of Rights. The second point is that our democratic rights are protected already. We live in a parliamentary democracy. We can kick out governments, State and Federal, of which we disapprove. Anyone can stand for parliament. Anyone can criticise publicly the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —In which State do you live?

—I was half expecting that interjection from Senator Colston on the other side of the chamber because of the comments made, both by people on his side and by the Australian Democrats, in respect of Queensland. Queenslanders are not stupid. They are a bunch of individuals, the same as people elsewhere in Australia. If they perceive that there has been an injustice in the electoral distributions in Queensland, that will be reflected in the ballot box.
—How can it be?

—I was intrigued by the fact that Senator Haines from the Democrats-who are the classic example of the pot calling the kettle black-has shown the greatest concern about the National Party of Australia gaining 39 per cent of first preference votes; yet they sit in this place making deals and playing God on the decisions of Australia with about 8 per cent of the vote.
—What do they get in Queensland?

—I think it was 2 per cent at the Redlands by-election. The civil and political rights of Australians have never been questioned and our legal rights are secured by the law. Unlawful government actions can be struck down in the courts.
—Where have you been all your life?

—I have always been amazed by the concern that people outside Queensland show for Queenslanders, but I do not see the concern within the State. Appropriate appeal mechanisms are in place. We have a burgeoning legal aid system and in the last 10 years we have seen enormous extensions of the protection of individuals against wrongful government actions, through freedom of information legislation, the office of the Ombudsman and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
—A public accounts committee?
—If the government of the day acts in ways which infringe our rights, let it suffer at the ballot box. I agree with the public accounts committee proposition.
—Why don't you do something about getting it, then?
—Tell me how.
—Through the ballot box, as you just said.
—I agree with the honourable senator that it should be done through the ballot box.
—You cannot even get enough to have a cricket team up there.

—I can recall that not so long ago the Australian Labor Party did not have enough members to have a reserve for a cricket team in Queensland and I suggest that after the next election it might be down to the size of a hockey team.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point, which is not original, is that many countries not possessing a Bill of Rights are free, tolerant and great respecters of human rights. Clearly, a Bill of Rights is not necessary for the protection of human rights. Is a Bill of Rights sufficient as a protective shield for our rights? Will a Bill of Rights alone safeguard our rights? The answer again is no. Firstly, this Bill of Rights does not protect all the rights that we as individuals surely possess in this country. It allows us to marry, to have children and to practise our religion and it protects us against torture. Strangely, it allows us to join a union, but not a union of our choice. It says nothing of our right not to join a union. It fails to protect our very basic rights to own and use private property for legitimate purposes.

Senator Haines has referred to both those items and she has said that she has some sympathy with the amendments proposed by the coalition. But, she goes on to say, in typical Democrat fashion, that she does not really like the sort of language in the amendments. So, we do not really know what she means, whether she agrees with us or not. In respect of private property I would like to quote from a letter by Eva Malonyay, Honorary Secretary of the Hungarian Council of the Australian Capital Territory, to the Canberra Times, in which she said:
At a debate . . . Mr Peter Bailey, the deputy chairman of the Human Rights Commission, defended the Government with alacrity.
He defended the Government in respect of the fact that the proposed Bill did not contain the right to own private property. The letter continued:
He told us that the original draft of the UN Covenant (our model) contained this article, but the USSR's objection caused it to be deleted.

Can honourable senators believe it? The USSR's objection caused the right to own private property to be deleted from a Bill of Rights which the Government is attempting to introduce into this country.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the light of the recent dramatic drop in farm values resulting from such factors as increased costs, largely attributable to this Government, and the Treasurer's anti-farm measures such as capital gains and fringe benefit taxes, will the Minister explain to farmers outside this building today how they can provide for their families, with an average farm income of only $6,700 per annum, when banks will not increase loans to those farmers because of the lack of security that their farms now provide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Farm prices, even in money terms, have dropped in different periods over the last 40 or 50 years. They have also dropped in recent times. They dropped from extraordinarily and unsustainably high levels. For some years, even in the more prosperous sections of Australian agriculture, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has assessed returns on capital investment in farms as being of the order of 2, 3 or 4 per cent. In other words, the market price of land was unsustainably high. One of the reasons that the market price of land reached those levels was the intention and expectation of reaping untaxed capital gains, both by people already in agriculture and people purchasing land who had not previously been associated with agriculture.

ANSWER.PARA: In other words, those pressures, supplemented to some extent by the availability of soft loans from the Primary Industry Bank of Australia which the then Government established in 1979, forced land prices up to unrealistically high levels. Farmers who bought land at that time-the great proportion of farmers who are currently in financial trouble in Australia bought land at that time-and in particular farmers in Queensland who bought assigned cane land--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the relationship to commodity prices? You should know it, because you are a farmer.

—Shut up, squeaky. Therefore, a major reason that significant numbers of farmers are in financial trouble today is the lack of a capital gains tax in the past and consequential speculation in agricultural land in the expectation of reaping untaxed capital gains. The BAE estimate of average nett farm income for this year of $6,700 is, I think, the figure to which Senator Chaney referred. As I have said in the Senate on a couple of previous occasions this week, that figure cannot be equated with wages because, first, it makes no allowance for imputed income although to get a proper comparability with wages, there should be an allowance and secondly, because it makes no allowance for income derived off the farm.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said yesterday, according to the Farm Investment Letter and the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales, more than 25 per cent of farmers will be hurt-to use their term-by the quarantining of farm losses. To be hurt both the following conditions have to be satisfied. First, the individual must be in receipt of off-farm income in excess of $20,000. Secondly, he must also be conducting a farming operation which is a tax loss and has been a tax loss for a number of years. In other words, if more that 25 per cent of farmers are hurt by those conditions, something like 50 per cent of farmers would have to be in receipt of off-farm income in excess of $20,000. I do not know whether those figures are correct. They are vastly in excess of the recorded figures for average off-farm income, but they are the figures endorsed by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales which is the sponsor of the demonstration outside Parliament House today, a demonstration which has been disowned by the National Farmers Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer, which helps to demonstrate why the Government has done so little to relieve the plight of farmers. Does the Minister suggest that the relatively low return on the value of rural land to which he referred in this answer is peculiar to Australia, or does he believe that similar returns have been received on farming land in those countries which have long had a capital gains tax, such as the United Kingdom and the United States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not so familiar with the average returns from agriculture in those countries. But I know, and can tell the honourable senator, that the two major causes of the escalation of land prices to ridiculously high levels, which took place about 1980 and for a year to two afterwards, were the availability of soft finance from the Primary Industry Bank of Australia and the expectation of untaxed capital gains from continually appreciating land prices. I also know that over the long term real agricultural land prices have not increased. Therefore, a capital gains tax tied to real gains will have no effect in the long term on the agricultural sector, except to eliminate harmful speculation in land prices by people seeking untaxed capital gains many of whom are outside agriculture, such as occurred in the early 1980s. For the benefit of the hooters in the Gallery I want it to be put on record that I have had personal experience as a farmer for 25 years. I still have some interest in a farm in partnership with my brother, but one of the reasons that that farm is not insolvent is that we reacted more rationally to particular circumstances than, unfortunately, is the norm in Australian agriculture.

ANSWER.PARA: An incident having occurred in the Gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is any other interjection from the Gallery I will see that the person concerned is removed.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Territories noticed that the use of corporal punishment will no longer be permitted in New South Wales government schools after this year? Does the Government intend to take similar action to end this barbaric practice in Australian Capital Territory government schools? If so, when can an announcement be expected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of Senator Colston's continued concern about the use of corporal punishment in the school education system as I am aware of the progressive actions that have been taken by the Minister for Education in the New South Wales Government in abolishing corporal punishment in the State education system. Of course, the Federal Government applauds that decision. Within the framework of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, however, a different system operates which gives each school in the Australian Capital Territory responsibility for making decisions about its operations including corporal punishment.

ANSWER.PARA: This includes the responsibility for determining its own discipline policies and sanctions which may cover corporal punishment. Schools electing to use corporal punishment must follow strict guidelines established by the Authority. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is mindful of the attitude taken by the Commonwealth Government. It is aware of our policy attitude that discourages the use of corporal punishment and urges schools to move towards its abolition. But we prefer to do that on the basis of persuading them to move towards the abolition of corporal punishment. I expect that most schools in a decentralised way would adopt that policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister mentioned that the Government will use persuasion. I wonder whether the Minister could indicate what the Government intends to do if such persuasion is not effective.

—One thing that we will not do is use corporal punishment. I am sure that the authorities and the headmasters in each school are aware of the Government's policy. However, seeing that Senator Colston perhaps requires a firmer direction than is currently the case, I will draw the matter to the attention of the Minister with the suggestion that perhaps the matter might proceed further along the road from persuasion to direction.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Why has the Government's much vaunted wages policy and agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions failed to prevent a week long strike in the coal industry? What action is the Government taking to end this strike which is costing Australia's largest export industry $20m a day and threatening its ability to succeed in an intensely competitive world market?

—The much vaunted wages policy of the Government to which Senator MacGibbon refers has been, as is widely recognised, very successful in terms of the economic performance of the Government. The wages policy in globo is not really strictly relevant to the situation in the coal mining industry. The stoppage in the coal mining industry is in breach of the provisions of the prices and incomes accord. I am asked what the Government is doing about that stoppage. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has been constantly in touch with the parties in an endeavour to obtain a quick settlement of the dispute. I totally agree with the implications in Senator MacGibbon's question about the importance of the strike in the coal industry for Australia's export trade. It is a most unfortunate decision by the coal mining unions to take industrial action which flows from a decision arrived at last year. The Government will continue to try to ensure that the dispute is resolved as quickly as possible. Again I make the point that I have often made in this chamber, that things of this kind which were commonplace under the previous Government are now things of considerable rarity in Australia and so they do stand out.
—But we could not get down to Canberra last week.

—Senator Boswell says that he could not get to Canberra, but I do not know what point there is in his coming here anyway. The simple point is that a strike like this one, which is of the utmost importance, stands out. Even Senator MacGibbon was able to be aware of it as a result of that fact. But the industrial relations record of this Government in terms of industrial disputes is the best in this country for 17 years. That is something about which the Government has legitimate reasons to be pleased-not satisfied, but pleased.
—Ask the farmers.

—I am not helped by Senator Walters's gestures. The record is a source of pleasure, not of satisfaction, for the Government. We have a long way to go to turn around cultural and social perceptions about industrial relations in this country because we are recovering from a legacy of failed industrial relations practices over many years, most of them under periods of Liberal conservative government.
