That task is not particularly helped by some of the nitwitted attempts at an industrial relations policy which, I understand from the Press, the present Opposition is engaged in considering.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the new determining system for veterans' pensions which has been in operation now for over 12 months. The Minister will be aware that all members and senators, myself included, have received a large number of complaints regarding delays in the system. Is the new system having the effect of reducing these delays and when will they reach acceptable levels?

—The Senate will be aware that for a number of years considerable problems have been associated with the determining system for pension applications. The recognition of that led the previous Government to refer to the Administrative Review Council a proposal that the system should be streamlined and improved. Therefore, the Senate took steps in 1984 with the starting point for the operation of a new system to be 1 January 1985. The purpose of the system is to reduce the unacceptably long delays in the system. It was not unusual for some applicants who were getting on in years to have to wait two, three or four years for their cases to be properly dealt with. The purpose of the new system was to improve the average of about a year's delay and to reach an objective of somewhere around 90 days from the point of receipt of the application to its being dealt with and a decision arrived at through the processes of the new determining system. We are now in a position in which we can see that that objective will be reached around the middle of this year. As at 1 July 1985 there were 41,000 applicants in the system. That figure has been reduced to 32,000 at the end of January. We are reasonably confident that, given the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill by the Senate and the solution of the problem between the two Houses, in about July of this year we will have reached the objective of about a 90-day delay. In those circumstances I think the veteran community, veteran organisations and the Parliament will be very happy that the new system is working effectively.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Government agree with President Reagan's reported statement yesterday that there has been no hard evidence of fraud in the Philippines elections? Whether the Government agrees or not, what action has it taken to make an accurate assessment of the situation? As future events in the Philippines are likely to impinge on Australia's security, will the Government undertake discussions with the Government of the USA in the interests of both nations achieving an honest and accurate understanding of and public position on the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Mr Hayden said earlier this week, the joint leaders of the international observer team organised by the United States Democrat and Republican parties noted that abuses and irregularities had occurred in the conduct of the poll. Likewise, Senator Lugar, the leader of the United States official observer team, said that his team had witnessed and heard disturbing reports of efforts to undermine the integrity of the official processes. These observer teams will not, however, issue final reports until the electoral process is complete and the result announced. We note further that in his statement on 11 February President Reagan said that the election had been flawed by reports of fraud and violence which the United States takes seriously.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, the Australian Government is very concerned, as Mr Hayden said, by these allegations of fraudulent conduct of the election. In making its final assessment of the conduct of the election, the Australian Government will take into account reports from not only the United States and the international observer groups but also Australian Embassy officials who observed polling in a wide range of areas throughout the Philippines. The formal outcome of the election is still unknown as the official count is still taking place in the National Assembly. It is not yet appropriate publicly to make an assessment of the election or to make an assessment of its significance for Australian interests and policy.

As to the last part of the question, the Australian Government maintains close and continuing contact with the United States on developments in the Philippines, including the election and subsequent developments. Obviously, we will be monitoring very closely the situation as it evolves and perhaps I will be in a position, like Mr Hayden, to make a more detailed response as events unfold over the next few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Australian newspaper of 31 December 1985 in which a Mr Peter Ryan, a wheat farmer from Canowindra, attributes his farm losses to increases in interest rates and fuel costs? Is the Minister in a position to indicate whether Mr Ryan's claims are accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that article. I read it the day it was published or perhaps the day after and I have a copy in front of me now. It is correct that in that article Mr Ryan is quoted as saying that his present difficult financial situation, if not insolvency, is attributable to increases in fuel prices and interest rates and that the changes in those two items have caused him to lose $100,000 in 1984-85. The article also states that in 1980 Mr Ryan took out a $500,000 loan. If one assumes that none of that loan principal was repaid in the interim period and interest rates between 1980 and 1984-85-that period to which these figures refer-increased by 5 per cent, the interest bill would have increased by $25,000. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics says that on wheat farms on average fuel costs make up somewhat less than 10 per cent of total farm costs. The same article says that Mr Ryan's total farm costs were $450,000; so if it is an average wheat farm, $45,000 would have been paid for fuel. Of that $45,000, $18,000 can be attributed to fuel price increases between 1980 and 1984-85. Therefore, at the most-I say `at the most' because it assumes that none of that loan money borrowed in 1980 had been repaid-the cost due to rising interest rates and fuel costs would have been of the order of $25,000 plus $18,000; that is, $43,000 in total.

ANSWER.PARA: Set against the reported loss of $100,000 in the year, Mr Ryan would have lost $57,000 even if fuel prices in money terms and interest rates had remained as they were in 1980. Particularly on wheat farms, incomes in any given year can be greatly affected by the yield but in that part of New South Wales in that year the wheat yield was average. Whether or not it was on Mr Ryan's farm is not disclosed. Needless to say, none of that analysis was included in the article published by the Australian. On the facts available in that article-none of which have been questioned, to the best of my knowledge-and on the 1984 results, that farm was headed for insolvency without any increase in the two items to which its financial plight has been attributed. It seems likely that a thorough examination would reveal that its plight had more to do with investment decisions made in 1980 or thereabouts than it did with changes inside Australia since that time.

It is true that because of external factors Australian agriculture in general is facing very bad terms of trade-mostly because of the long-standing policies of the European Economic Community-which terms have now been exacerbated by the recent retaliatory action by the United States. Australian agriculture has known such periods before and, in reference to Senator Chaney's first question, this is not the first time that agricultural land prices, even in money terms, have fallen. Precisely the same thing happened in the 1970-71-72 period when of course the Liberal-Country Party Government was in power. It is fortuitous, or appropriate, that there was broadcast this morning on AM an interview with a farmer from the area in question, Canowindra in New South Wales. This farmer, Mr Bill Pollard, said of the people who organised the gathering here today:

They've really lost touch with the farming community if they believe the things they are currently saying because not all farmers are in the dire straits that they claim they are . . . I would think that most farmers will make sufficient money to pay a little bit of tax this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the papers from which he has quoted during his answer.
—Will the Minister table the papers from which he has quoted?
—The paper is a sheet of handwritten notes.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the remarks I made yesterday about the length of questions and answers. If honourable senators' questions could be brief and Ministers' answers a little more brief it would help everyone at Question Time.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce satisfied with the progress in the reduction of the number of car models being produced by Australian manufacturers in line with the objectives of the Government's motor vehicle plan? When does the Minister envisage the number of local car manufacturers being reduced from five to three? What impact will the fall in the value of the Australian dollar and the Government's proposed new tax on company cars have on the implementation and success of the Government's plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question is whether I am satisfied with progress in the reduction in the number of models under the car plan. The answer is yes. Secondly, I am asked when the number of manufacturers in Australia will be reduced from five to three. It is important to indicate that we never used quite that expression; we said that we saw the five companies forming themselves into three consortia or something of that kind. I cannot say I am satisfied with that progress but I cannot say I am dissatisfied at this stage. Progress is being made on that issue, and certainly it is being made on the model reduction issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot make any precise statement about the effects of the devaluation of the Australian dollar on the motor vehicle industry. It seems that for most of the calendar year 1985 the effects of the devaluation were accommodated by price reductions in respect of imported parts and components. That process came to an end late last year. A significant proportion of motor vehicle componentry is imported, and the effects have been quite differential. For example, General Motors-Holden's Ltd has probably suffered more than others as a result of its decision made before the devaluation to import six-cylinder engines from Japan. That has been a difficult decision for that company to accommodate. Had it made another decision it might have been better in a number of ways, but that is a matter for the company.

The best thing that I can say about the effects of the fringe benefits tax package on the motor industry is that the industry has expressed some concern and in fact different sectors of the industry have expressed slightly different concerns. We are in discussion with them about those concerns. When the legislation is presented to the Parliament we will see whether those discussions have had any effect on the existing package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry been drawn to statements by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry concerning corrupted world markets for agricultural commodities? Can the Minister estimate how important this situation is in terms of the debt servicing problems currently facing agriculture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to quantify the effects of the corrupted world markets on the income position and therefore the debt servicing capacity of Australian agriculture. It is indisputably true that the major cause of the change in farmers' terms of trade that has occurred in the last couple of years has been the oversupply of markets for the majority of Australia's agricultural commodities, which itself is attributable to what the Prime Minister and Mr Kerin call the corruption of world markets, particularly by the European Economic Community and more recently the United States. That adverse movement in the terms of trade has been offset to a significant degree by the devaluation of the Australian dollar. Nevertheless, the terms of trade have moved against Australian farmers quite appreciably. As I noted before, it is not the first time that that has happened. Something very similar happened in the early 1970s.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been a longer term structural problem in the Australian economy, which was referred to as recently as last Monday by, at that stage, an ex-Liberal Party member of the Western Australian Parliament. He said that most of it was due to the National Party of Australia, as it is called these days. Of course, if one takes a long term view about the structure of the Australian economy, he is correct in saying that most of what is wrong with it is due to the National Party and that adverse effects of that long term structural problem are felt by sections at least of the agricultural sector. Indeed, Mr McNee said that day:
If they--
he was talking about members of the National Party, which uses different names in different parts of the country--
had performed well over the 30 years they held the primary industry portfolio at the Federal and State levels, then the rural industries would never be the way they are now . . .

Of course, he is absolutely correct. If the National Party had performed decently over the 30 years that it held the State portfolio in most States-or for a greater part of that period the State portfolio in most States-and for virtually all that period the portfolio in the Federal Parliament, the structural problems of the Australian economy which hurt farmers and other sectors would not be doing the damage they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were no protests when we were in government.
—For the benefit of Senator Brownhill, I pass on to him the Liberal Party's advice. Mr McNee said:

ANSWER.PARA: It--
again talking about the National Party--
wants to stop talking about tariff and remember that John McEwen was the architect of the tariff system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General name the active members of the Human Rights Commission? Are there any inactive members and, if so, why?
—That is a question with a number of connotations. I think I had better sort it out with the Attorney-General before I offer a reply.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I am well aware that the Minister has knowledge of this. I wonder why he has to sort it out with the Attorney-General.
—Order! No supplementary question is involved.

—Mr President, I am indebted to Senator Walters for her suggestion that I am in full knowledge of who is doing what and who is active, retired or inactive on the Commission, but I am afraid I am not. I will need to seek that advice from the Attorney-General.

—Has the Minister for Education seen the article in the Melbourne Herald of 13 February which states that tertiary students are being forced to cut their courses to part time so that they can get the dole? Can the Minister advise whether this is the case? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the number of students receiving assistance under the tertiary education assistance scheme and the amount of money which the Federal Government grants to students? Finally, is TEAS the only form of financial assistance available to tertiary students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article referred to in Senator McKiernan's question has been drawn to my attention. I point out to Senator McKiernan and other honourable senators that it is estimated that in 1985 106,750 students received TEAS benefits and that that payment cost $262m. This year it is estimated that 113,900 students will receive TEAS benefits at a cost of $302m. So it is evident from those figures that our Government places a high priority on responding to the problems faced by young Australians and to assisting those young Australians who are pursuing tertiary studies. In 1987 an age-related scheme of financial assistance will be introduced for young people aged 16 to 20 years with differential rates of allowance for 16 and 17-year-olds and those aged 18 and over. This development will mean that there is no financial incentive at all for students to seek unemployment benefit rather than tertiary assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: The person quoted in the article is Mr Chris Kirwan, a student counsellor at the Melbourne College of Advanced Education. Mr Kirwan has claimed that not enough research is going on into student finances. I would like to point out to the Senate and to Mr Kirwan that in recent years there have been three major surveys of student finances together with other commissioned studies. My Department's own publications in the studies of student finances series now amount to four volumes of over 550 pages. Moreover, other studies of student issues, such as attrition rates, have also examined student financial problems. I think it is strange that Mr Kirwan, who has made the complaint, comes from the Melbourne CAE when another student adviser at the same college, Mr Vince Callaghan, is a member of the advisory committee for one of my Department's studies in this field. I think it is clear that our Government has considerably increased the level of TEAS and significantly greater numbers of students are now eligible for and are taking the TEAS payments.

I say in conclusion that students would be ill-advised to cut down to part time studies in the hope of being able to be eligible for the dole because they will then be extending the period it would take them to get their degree and have that very valuable asset. I would also point out that the availability of casual employment has increased considerably and that students are in a much better position now than they were in the recession of the Fraser years to supplement TEAS payments with casual work, which, of course, has been traditional amongst Australian students.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS: PRODUCTIVITY CLAIM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Australian Council of Trade Unions President, Mr Simon Crean, said in a recent newspaper article that, if employers try to block its three per cent productivity claim, the ACTU would commence a guerilla campaign to achieve its objectives. Why has the Government not shown any concern about the ultimate attack on the basic freedoms of Australians and the frontal attack on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission? Is not the trade union attitude totally inconsistent with the rule of law and government by those elected to govern?

—I have not seen any statement by Mr Crean, but, in saying that, I am not asserting that it was not said in any sense; it may well have been. I am not intending to embark on a philosophical discussion about the basic freedoms of Australians. I would just remind honourable senators about what was said by the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, Mr Justice Maddern, at the start of the national wage case proceedings a week or two ago when he said that those proceedings would be adjourned if any industrial action was taken in respect of any matter, including superannuation. That is the appropriate pronouncement from the appropriate figure in respect of this matter. The Government has made it quite clear that it does not support industrial action in respect of this or any other matter and will continue to do so. But the sanction, as it were, is appropriately in the Arbitration Commission and that is where it has been exercised by the President.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAYMENTS OF SPECIAL BENEFITS TO UNSUPPORTED SCHOOL STUDENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security please give an indication of the Government's response to the recent decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the case relating to the payment of special benefits to unsupported school students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has informed me that the Government has decided not to appeal to the Federal Court of Australia against the decision to which the honourable senator refers. The four students who appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will, therefore, be paid arrears of special benefit as directed by the Tribunal. The Department has issued an instruction to apply the terms of the decision to all similar cases and the guidelines of the Department have been amended accordingly. This is in line with the Government's commitment to provide adequate income for people who need it.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators may know, the Government recently announced a new unsupported youth allowance for people under 18 with no other means of support, whether they are in education or whether they are looking for work. This allowance, together with a range of other Priority One initiatives, will place the treatment of unsupported youths under 18 on a regular basis. We believe that resolving the crisis of youth unemployment and youth poverty-I might add left as a relic of the policies of the previous Government-is one of our greatest challenges and we will continue to attack it in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Will the Government repudiate the public statement made by the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, in Hobart after this week's Australian Agricultural Council meeting that current protests by farmers had more to do with politics than with farm prices, and that their aggravation was not necessarily related to their current financial situation? Was the Minister for Primary Industry reflecting Government policy? Does it indicate a governmental rejection of last week's appeal by the Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Dr Stoeckel, for the Government to change its rural policies because `in the absence of alleviating policy initiatives, the farm sector is confronted by severe financial stress' along with industries supplying it and country towns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The farm sector is confronted with some severe financial stress, though not nearly as severe, I suggest, as the financial stress suffered by people who were sucked in to invest money through Patrick Partners about 15 years ago after that firm went bust when Senator Baume was a partner in it. —I address my question to the Minister representing the Attorney- General. In view of the tragic family shooting which occurred in Canberra yesterday, will the Attorney-General's Department move promptly to implement legislation in the Australian Capital Territory similar to existing legislation in New South Wales and South Australia covering domestic violence, which allows people immediate injunctions preventing partners from approaching or communicating with them? Furthermore, can the Minister advise what action the Federal Government can take to introduce similar legislation under Commonwealth family law so that there is protection for all Australian women across the States regardless of the failure of some States-particularly, I regret, my home State of Queensland-to recognise the urgency of such protective legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have of course seen the report of this week's appalling shooting in Canberra. While it may be that events of this kind involving extreme pathological behaviour can never be completely avoided, it is the case that the Attorney-General intends to reform the law of the Australian Capital Territory relating to domestic violence to ensure that more effective protection is given by the law to persons affected by domestic violence-for example, by providing for the making of summary restraining orders-and to ensure that the perpetrators of such violence, when it does occur, are adequately dealt with. Outside the territories, the difficulty for the Federal Government is that it has no constitutional power over domestic violence or de facto relationships. This is a matter of State responsibility. In New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania, the laws have been changed to allow for the making of an order where actual or threatened personal injury or damage to property is likely to occur unless an offender is restrained by the court. A breach of the order is a criminal offence. The focus in all five States is to use court orders to prevent and deter further acts of violence while also improving protection to victims. The State laws cover both married and de facto spouses. Where the Commonwealth has the constitutional power in the area of marriage it already has in force legislation of a similar nature. Under section 114 of the Family Law Act the courts can grant an injunction restraining certain behaviour of one party for the personal protection of the other or of a child of the marriage. Another provision allows attachment to the injunction of a power of arrest without warrant in a case of actual or threatened breach. A further provision specifically preserves the concurrent State legislation in areas where that exists. State police assistance is, as a result, available to prosecute offences under State domestic violence laws.

ANSWER.PARA: I summarise it by saying that the Commonwealth policy is to ensure operation of these criminal procedures to deal with domestic violence, but also to leave open the civil remedies under the Family Law Act. It is not to have the Family Court deal with domestic violence as a criminal offence, as that court's philosophy is to promote conciliation. I will raise with the Attorney-General the need to exert as much pressure as is possible on State and Territory Attorneys-General to give high priority to reform in an area where this is so obviously needed and to the provision of adequate resources to effectively enforce existing legislation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that an endeavour has been made by Australian ex-servicemen who were placed in concentration camps in Germany and Czechoslovakia during World War II to seek some form of reparations or compensation from the West German Government. It was not until 1982 that the previous Government, the Liberal-National Party Government, decided to make representations to the West German Government in respect of those matters and it received no assurances that compensation would be paid.

ANSWER.PARA: However, since the change of government in 1983, Mr Hayden and I have had several discussions with respect to this matter and an inter-departmental committee has been established under the chairmanship of the Department of Foreign Affairs with representatives from other interested departments, such as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury, for example, as well as the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The IDC recognise that there is a substantial case for some form of compensation for the dwindling number of ex-prisoners of war who were placed in concentration camps because they were considered too unreliable by the nazis for ordinary POW camps. Their unreliability by nazi standards was determined by their attempts to escape and to organise against the nazi regime.

There is no question but that some equity should be available to Australian ex-servicemen. The Government believes that there is a prima facie case for some form of compensation. The difficulty is that the West German Government is not sympathetic to the proposals. Constant endeavours are being made to try to shift the West German Government in this respect. All I can tell Senator Sibraa is that the Government is determined to press on with the matter. We are not prepared to accept the negative attitude that is being taken by the West German Government. We are hopeful that some progress will be made, even if finally it has to come down to some form of ex gratia payment to the dwindling number of Australian prisoners of war. As Senator Sibraa suggests, the film Death Wears a Smile shows the degree of persecution, torture and other inhuman activities that were carried out in the concentration camps. We believe that there is a very genuine case for the West German Government's accepting some responsibility for reparation in these matters.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is the Government concerned about the problems facing the unemployed who are renting privately? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

We also hope that they will be assisted by increases in the amount of housing funds available for public housing, for which many of these people are eligible. From May this year rental assistance of up to $10 a week will be available to unemployment and special beneficiaries aged 18 years or more who pay private rent and who have been in receipt of such benefits for at least six months. ANSWER.PARA: In targeting this assistance to the long term unemployed and in restricting the eligibility for younger unemployed people living at home, the Government has been concerned to ensure that the maximum benefit is paid to those most in need and likely to have a high proportion of their income devoted to rent. DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1985HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985AUSTRALIAN BILL OF RIGHTS BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch I had been referring to the lack of provision in the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for individuals in Australia to own private property. I referred to the remarks made by Mr Peter Bailey, the Deputy Chairman of the Human Rights Commission, who defended the Government from the point of view that this provision was not in the Bill. On 1 December 1985, Mr Bailey told people in a debate in Canberra that the original draft of the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the model we have before us, contained this Article, but the objection of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics caused it to be deleted. The USSR's objection has caused the provision for people to own private property to be deleted from the Australian Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also says nothing about the right of parents to send their children to a school of their choice-and this at a time when the Government is making it harder for people to start new private schools or extend existing ones. So this Bill protects only some of our rights. This is not surprising, because when one comes to define rights, it is inevitable that rights will be limited. It is interesting to note the rights that it leaves out. It would appear that the Government is denying that we have such rights as the right not to join a union. If so, how can the Government be serious about its concern for our rights? The Bill, of course, can be repealed by any future government. It will be repealed by us when we go back to government. So the rights the Bill refers to are transitory rights. They are to be protected only while this Government remains in office. How can such rights therefore be said to be guaranteed by this Bill? Such a claim is absolute nonsense.

Secondly-and this point again is widely made-no Bill can make people tolerant of the rights of others. The Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, is well aware of this, and the Government should be aware of it.

Thirdly, many countries which have a Bill of Rights are very oppressive regimes with scant regard for basic freedoms. The Soviet Union has a terrific constitution, with all sorts of democratic guarantees built into it. It has been called a model constitution. So much for a Bill of Rights guaranteeing human rights. Clearly, no Bill of Rights, and certainly not this Bill of Rights, can protect our fundamental freedoms. This legislation is not sufficient for rights. Why, then, do we have this package of Bills before us? Quite simply, it is a political tool for the Government to attack State governments that it wants to hurt politically-and it hounds these governments through the Human Rights Commission, of course. There is a secondary reason for the Bill. It panders to the burgundy socialists who want to feel warm inside and to be seen to be caring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the white wine whingers?

—That is correct, Senator. But the main reason for the Bill is political. The Human Rights Commission-the new Australian thought police, as it has been described by others-already has a reputation of meddling in affairs in which it really has no concern. It already acts in a quasi-judicial way. For example, in answer to a request from a Labor senator last year, the Commission was used to examine the Electrical Trades Union strike in Queensland as a political weapon.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Human Rights Commission will be strengthened under this legislation, and it will be used to score political points against opponents of the Government in accordance with the Bill of Rights. The Human Rights Commission last year refused access to a senior respected politician who happened to disagree with things it was doing, without giving him the decency of a fair hearing.

In conclusion, the Bill is not about protecting rights; it is about thought control and political point scoring. This Bill is not necessary to protect rights, nor is it sufficient to protect rights. It will arm bureaucrats with a mechanism to embarrass State governments for political purposes. The Federal Government has already used the Commission in this way and it will do it again and again. We in the coalition are opposed to the Bill of Rights and will seek to repeal it on being returned to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this package of legislation-the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill 1985 and cognate Bills. It is perhaps an interesting point to observe that despite the range of opinion and the range of views which exist within the Liberal Party and National Party Opposition on a number of issues, including issues related to human rights, to equal opportunities and to a number of related matters, nevertheless we are all at one in believing that this is a flawed piece of legislation and it is not the correct course of action to be pursued in a legislative sense by the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. We believe that the Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 is in fact not the most effective way to protect and safeguard the rights of ordinary Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that, as a non-lawyer, I am singularly unimpressed with the argument frequently trotted out that the common law protects the rights of all citizens. Clearly it does not. In Australia, the principle that most people would wish to adhere to, that of equality of voting rights, was indicated by the High Court of Australia in McKinlay's case not to have any constitutional or legal protection. The State has the right to impose civil conscription, and the discussion of this in the Human Rights Commission report on the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985 is worth reading.

There is no right for the protection of private property. One often hears the claim that this is protected under Commonwealth law, nevertheless the High Court in the Teori Tau case in 1969 said that this protection did not apply to the Territories. We have seen in 1981, with the passage of the New South Wales Coal Acquisition Act, that it certainly does not apply within State jurisdictions.

One would have thought that jury trial was something protected in Australia. Nevertheless, as His Honour Mr Justice Deane commented recently in the case of Clyne v. the Director of Public Prosecutions:

The guarantee of trial by jury which is contained in section 80 of the Constitution has been drained of most of its strength by the combined effect of legislation of the Parliament and decisions of the Court.

One would have thought, for instance, that the right to practise religion freely in Australia existed. It does not. The High Court, in the case of the Grace Bible Church Inc. v. Reedman, decided in 1984, made it absolutely clear that that was the case. Indeed, Mr Justice Millhouse, in the South Australian Supreme Court, referring to South Australia, stated:
The citizens of this State do not have rights which may not be overriden by Act of the South Australian Parliament.

He was referring to the question of freedom of religion. One would have thought that the right of privacy existed in Australia. It does not. The High Court in the Victoria Park Racing case in 1937 said, basically: `If you want privacy, build higher fences'. In the case of the Church of Scientology v. Woodward, decided again by the High Court in 1982, it was made clear that there was no right to privacy established in Australia.
Lastly, one should draw attention to the judgment of His Honour Mr Justice Dunn in the Queensland Supreme Court in the case of Fischer v. Douglas, in which he said:

In Queensland, because of the sovereignty of Parliament, the subject does not have guaranteed rights. Those who describe themselves as the champions of civil liberties frequently speak of such liberties as though there were no such thing as the sovereignty of Parliament; and, when they address themselves to the uncomprehending and the emotional, they may consequently mislead their audience.

I do not want to mislead any audience by indicating that civil rights are adequately and properly protected in Australia at the moment. They are not. The question before us is: Is the Bill of Rights the correct way to protect those rights? I, in association with all members of the Opposition, would argue that that is not the case.

The case I want, therefore, to put before the Senate is not that civil rights do not need protecting, but simply that they need protecting by a more effective method than the proposed package of legislation which comes before us today. I believe that if one looks at the experience of the effect of the Racial Discrimination Act and the Sex Discrimination Act, one sees that it indicates the way in which Parliament ought to address itself, not in a global sense but in a series of case by case circumstances, to issues as they arise and be sensitive to the fact that different rights need protection by different mechanisms. In the time available to debate this legislation, one cannot go any further than to state that as a general principle, without going into the specific details of how that ought to be achieved.

Again, if I may comment as a non-lawyer, the one thing that I am most concerned about as a consequence of the Bill of Rights, if it were to be enacted, would be the transfer of power and responsibility from the elected parliament into the hands of the judiciary. If one wants to see this discussed, I think in its most clear fashion, it is worth turning to a debate which took place in the House of Lords on 29 November 1978. The House of Lords had before it a report from a select committee on the establishment of a Bill of Rights for Great Britain. For those who want to criticise the International Covenant on the basis that it is not signed by the United Kingdom, it is interesting to note that the House of Lords, hardly an institution regarded as the revolutionary champion of all that is new and wonderful, nevertheless by vote resolved that the provisions of the European Convention dealing with civil and political rights should in fact be enacted into domestic legislation in the United Kingdom. That vote, which was carried by 56 votes to 30, is recorded clearly in the House of Lords. Let me take a couple of extracts from the House of Lords debate. I think the most significant contribution made in the House of Lords debate was that made by Lord Diplock, a very distinguished British judge, who said:

It is inevitable in a modern society, in which judges have to interpret social legislation about which strong political views are held on either side, that this tends to bring judges into the political arena . . . If we are to pass a Bill of rights . . . it is inevitable that the tendency will increase, because a Bill of Rights in that form compels the Judiciary to make political decisions.

I do not want to see the judiciary making political decisions. They are not elected to make political decisions and, if I may say with the greatest of respect to them, when one considers their background, social standing, education and attitudes, I do not think they are qualified to make political decisions. To that extent I believe that, so long as that responsibility lies with an elected parliament, we should not put it off into other people's hands. Lord Hailsham, the very distinguished British Lord Chancellor, in his contribution to the debate indicated something which I think is of very considerable significance when one looks at the package of legislation before us. Lord Hailsham said in the debate:

The Sex Discrimination Act is about 75 pages long and the Race Relations Act, three of them in the last 10 years, are about another 80 pages long. I would prefer a single sentence which said that people of all races should be treated alike and for the judges to view those cases as and when they arise. But, then, I am a lone voice speaking in the wilderness and everyone is very conservative, except me.

I think it is a telling and interesting point that the sheer complexity of legislation tends to be more likely to obscure and make difficult the protection of rights than in fact to guarantee the protection of rights.

I turn, therefore, to the United States and indicate by reference to the American Bill of Rights the extent to which the influence of the judges has caused the Bill of Rights in the United States to be interpreted in a way entirely different from that which was intended by the politicians who wrote the Bill of Rights in the first place. Despite the dictum, I think, of Tommy Cochranes that the Supreme Court follows the election returns, nevertheless there are a couple of points to be made. The American Bill of Rights-the first 10 Amendments to the United States Constitution-was enacted in 1791. Article 1 provided that there should be no establishment of religion and that there should be no congressional legislation to abridge the right of free speech. None of us would object to that. But under the rulings of the Court, the concept that there should be no established religion, in the case of Abington v. Schempp in 1963, saw the Court rule that it was unconstitutional to have Bible readings in schools. In the case of Murray v. Curlett, again in 1963, it ruled that it was unconstitutional for schools to have prayer sessions. On the issue of free speech, Congress shall make no laws abridging free speech, but in the case of Roth v. USA in 1957, the Court ruled that as a result, legislation against obscenity and pornography was in breach of the First Amendment. Indeed, in United States v. Reidel in 1971, it ruled that it was unconstitutional to prevent the transmission of pornography through the mail system.

Article 2 of the Bill of Rights indicates that United States citizens are to have the right to bear arms, the need for what their Constitution refers to as a well-armed militia. In United States v. Cruikshank, decided back in 1876, and in Miller v. Texas in 1894, gun control laws have been struck down by interpreting a statute of 1791 in terms, perhaps relative to 1791, but certainly not relative to contemporary American requirement and practices. The Eighth Article of the Bill of Rights in the United States contains a prohibition against what it calls cruel and unusual punishment. Nothing could be more cruel and unusual than the behaviour of the judges, who in 1972, in the case of Furman v. Georgia, struck down the death penalty and in 1976 in the case of Gregg v. Georgia, restored the death penalty. Nothing had happened to change the wording of the Eighth Amendment, but the composition of the American Supreme Court bench had changed and the attitudes of the judges had changed. If anything was cruel and unusual it was the process of abolishing the death penalty by judicial fiat and then restoring it by judicial fiat.

In 1868 the Fourteenth Amendment to the American Constitution was added-the so-called equal rights and due process amendment. Under that we got to the stage where in the case of Roe v. Wade in 1973, the due process amendment and the right to privacy were taken to be sufficient for the court to declare that laws preventing abortion were unconstitutional. Again, if one is looking for twists and turns of judicial interpretation, under the Fourteenth Amendment, in Plessy v. Ferguson in 1896, the court ruled that racial segregation could occur, sep- arate but equal, it said. It took them until 1954 in the case of Brown v. Board of Education to determine that separate and equal was no longer a valid doctrine. The legislation had not changed. The Bill of Rights had not changed. The Fourteenth Amendment had not changed, but the judges had changed.

If one looks, finally, at the Nineteenth Amendment, which deals with voting rights, a poll tax was upheld in 1937 in the case of Breedlove v. Suttles, and literacy tests in 1959 in the case of Lassiter v. Northampton Election Board were upheld. They were all struck down in the landmark cases to which reference has already been made-Baker v. Carr in 1962 and Reynolds v. Sims in 1964. The recitation of that is simply to demonstrate that in a piece of legislation as complex as the Bill of Rights we are requiring the judiciary to make a number of political decisions. There is neither certainty, nor indeed is there the sort of adherence to precedent over a long period of time, that one would want in terms of the question of the protection of fundamental human rights. This is not to say by any means that international instruments dealing with the protection of human rights cannot serve as extremely valuable guides for interpretation. A point which Senator Durack made, largely in response to gross and unfair provocation by Senator Cooney, was to indicate that the attachment of the International Covenant as a schedule to the earlier piece of legislation was intended as a guide and was intended to establish certain principles, not to enshrine them in law. As a member of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I participated in the investigation and the reporting of a reference dealing with the Bill of Rights. That report, entitled `A bill of rights for Australia? Exposure report', indicated the experience of the United Kingdom. I will read paragraph 6.6 of that report, which deals with the way in which the United Kingdom has modified its domestic law as a result of rulings by the European Court of Human Rights and has done so in order to bring about some conformity to those laws, but has not been required or compelled to do so. It has done so because its intention has been drawn to deficiencies in its domestic law and the Parliament of the United Kingdom has acted to give effect to changes in order to safeguard more adequately the rights in question. The report states:

6.6 Findings of the European Court of Human Rights have contributed to various changes in the domestic laws and practice in the United Kingdom. These have included amendments to Prison Rules (Golder's Case); a change in Scottish Education Department policy in regard to corporal punishment (Campbell and Cosans' Case) and proposed legislation in the United Kingdom to enable parents to exempt a child from corporal punishment (Tyrer's Case); enactment of the Contempt of Court Act 1981 (Sunday Times' Case); enactment of the Employment Act 1980 to amend trade union legislation to protect the right to freedom of association (Closed Shop Case); enactment of the Mental Health (Amendment) Act 1982 (X v. UK); changes to legislation regulating homosexual conduct (Dudgeon's Case); enactment of the Interception of Communications Act 1985 to implement a Government White Paper (Malone's Case). The jurisdiction of the European Court has also produced a greater awareness of human rights considerations in the United Kingdom in the drafting of legislation.

There we see clearly indicated in a Senate Committee report a more effective method of protecting and safeguarding human rights, dealing with them on a case by case, example by example, basis, without the whole paraphernalia of a Bill of Rights and the whole paraphernalia of an attendant lot of judges and lawyers at work under the sort of regime that the Bill of Rights, as proposed by the Government, would establish.

I turn to the legislation which deals with the Human Rights Commission. Let me say first and clearly that the Human Rights Commission was a creation of a previous Liberal-National Party government, and a good creation at that. I also say that the official policy of the Liberal and National parties is for the maintenance of the Human Rights Commission. I will read into the record the section of our Policy on Law and Justice dealing with this-a policy on which we went to the last Federal election. I quote from page 4 under the heading `Human Rights and Liberties':
We-
we refers to the Liberal and National parties; we both co-sponsored this document-

believe that human rights and civil liberties are best preserved and advanced by the effective operation of our parliamentary and judicial traditions rather than the creation of new institutions or an entrenched Bill of Rights. Indeed the most effective way of enhancing freedom at the present time is to have fewer and more simplified laws.

The past four decades has seen an incredible increase in the volume and complexity of legislation which has largely become unmanageable and unintelligible. We believe that this process must stop. Insofar as new laws are required, Parliament should lay-down general rather than highly detailed guidelines leaving the courts to apply the object and purpose of the legislation to specific cases.
We will take firm steps to reduce the volume of legislation and will review existing legislation with the object of repealing and simplifying a great deal of it.

The Human Rights Commission should be substantially an advisory body within its charter and should not be allowed to become a great new bureaucracy which itself may pose threats to the rights and liberties of some sections of the community on the pretext of enhancing the rights of others.
More reasonable and humane standards of expression and behaviour are better achieved by education and social pressure than legal sanctions.

I turn to several points in that document. Laws ought to be simpler and more easily understandable. This is a point that was made in a House of Lords debate by Lord Hailsham. The courts should be guided by the expression made by Parliament as to the purpose of law. That is the reason why, when the Liberal-National Party Government enacted the Freedom of Information Act, it put for the first time into that Act a series of sections at the beginning stating the objects and the purposes of the Act. That was why when we were in government we amended the Acts Interpretation Act to require the courts to have more regard to the express purposes stated by the Parliament in the legislation, in the explanatory memoranda and in the relevant second reading speeches of Ministers.

In our policy document we state that the Human Rights Commission should be substantially an advisory body. We are committed to retaining the Human Rights Commission and we believe it should be retained fundamentally in its existing form. We do not believe that it should be turned into a body having essentially all full time members and participants. We value the role played by the part time members who bring to the Commission a degree of expertise and of special knowledge and interest which we think is particularly valuable. We do not believe in expanding the Human Rights Commission, in particular when one looks at the Minister's second reading speech, to get into such areas as adjudication on International Labour Organisation conventions. The Minister mentions ILO Convention No. 111 of 1973 dealing with equal opportunity. That in itself raises a whole different issue.

That raises the issue of the extent to which it is proper to allow the continuation of Executive power to bind Australia to international instruments and treaties without reference to the elected Parliament for ratification. That is a matter which several honourable senators have addressed from time to time and on which there are notices on the Senate Notice Paper proposing a method whereby the Senate at least, as the House representing the constituent States of the Federation, should have a role in approving or disapproving of Australia's entry into international treaty obligations exclusively by Executive action.

I believe that the Human Rights Commission has some achievements to its credit. In its publication of this month entitled `A Summary of the Activities and Achievements of the Human Rights Commission', it is interesting to note that to December 1975 the Commission had received 9,882 complaints. It had received 7,353 complaints about racial discrimination, some 1,300 complaints about sexual discrimination and an additional 1,223 complaints made under the Human Rights Commission Act. It is therefore clear that the Commission in its present form, in the form in which it was established by the Liberal and National parties, has been able to play a significant and useful role in the promotion and protection of human rights under the existing Human Rights Commission Act, under the existing Racial Discrimination Act and under the existing Sex Discrimination Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who appointed the commissioners, do you know?

—The commissioners were appointed by a previous government. They were appointed by a Liberal-National Party government and it was our practice in government to appoint to bodies such as the Human Rights Commission only those persons who we regarded as fully competent and qualified to undertake the considerable responsibilities vested in them. I believe that from time to time the Human Rights Commission may have strayed from what we would regard as the straight and narrow. I am looking at a publication entitled `Teaching for Human Rights' by Ralph Pettman, which publication is endorsed by the Human Rights Commission. One would want to be reasonably critical of the text of this particular publication. I do not like the section on page 96 which describes the existing Australian economic and social system. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A system like this, that places its first priority upon personal achievement and competitive success, taking only a secondary interest in communal welfare, leaves many individuals at risk.

That is absolute nonsense and garbage. We ought to have a system in which the first priority is on personal achievement and competitive success. I know that Senator Ryan does not believe in that. She also believes in the destruction of the decent Australian education system so I am not really concerned about her views. While one can make the odd criticism about the work of the Human Rights Commission, from time to time any organisation such as the Commission will find that it is the centre of some political controversy or vigorous public debate.

Nevertheless, the previous Liberal and National Party Government established it to do a job which, in my submission, it has done well and competently. I and the Opposition do not believe, therefore, that it needs to be tinkered with. We have a clear policy commitment to preserve it and to confine it to an advisory role because, exactly as I said about the judiciary, it is not the role of judges nor of the human rights Commission to undertake activities which enforce human rights other than those which are guaranteed, protected and directed by the Parliament. That is what members of Parliament are elected to do. That is the responsibility that they have to discharge. It is simply not right and proper to seek, by enactment of the Bill of Rights Bill, or indeed by expansion of the Human Rights Commission through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, to take out of the hands of this Parliament fundamental responsibility and accountability for ensuring that human rights are adequately protected. Therefore, we oppose both pieces of legislation.

Finally, we will also seek to test the bona fides of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats by proposing a series of amendments if this Bill passes the second reading stage and if the Senate does not send the legislation to a committee for further examination. We will invite the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to take cognisance of a couple of fundamental claims: The claim not to be coerced to join a trade union and the claim not to be coerced into allowing one's property to be stolen by the State. We will see just how selective or otherwise are members of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats about the protection of human rights.

We will ask them to explain why the right not to join a trade union and the right to hold private property are not of equal value to the right to express one's opinion by demonstrating in the streets or to express it by use of freedom of speech clauses in the Bill of Rights. In other amendments we will deal with such rights as those to undertake research and scientific study and we will see whether the Government and the Democrats are serious about protecting rights or whether their selectivity about rights is a function of their political ideology. We oppose this Bill, not because we believe that civil and human rights do not need to be protected, but because we believe that they need to be protected in a far more effective, serious and responsible fashion than is proposed by the Government in this package of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today on the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and cognate Bills because I believe that they are some of the most dangerous Bills to have been introduced into the Parliament since Federation. I certainly intend to vote against them. I cannot understand why the Government should decide to bring in this outrageous legislation. This Government is known throughout Australia for causing high interest rates, fuel prices and unemployment and it has been responsible for farmers-as we saw today outside Parliament House-small business people and motorists all over Australia becoming irate. Now we have another very large group of irate people across the nation who are furious about the Australian Bill of Rights. At least 1,200 letters have been sent to my office. I am sure that all other honourable senators will have had many letters about this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I spoke at a meeting in Toowoomba on the Bill of Rights. I suggested to the people there that they did not need to send letters to coalition senators because the coalition had made its situation quite clear. We have said that we will oppose the Bill of Rights and associated Bills. The Australian Labor Party has said that it will support them. So the people at the meeting knew where the Labor Party stood. I suggested that they should send letters to the Australian Democrats because, at that time, the Democrats had not made their stand on this matter. Today we heard Senator Haines say that they knew where they were going and that they would support the Bill of Rights. I believe that the Bill of Rights will lay the foundation for a massive shift of power in Australia. The hypocrisy of the Bill is such that it threatens the very rights and freedoms that it purports to protect. It is a blueprint for a socialist reconstruction of the federal system of government, the education system and the judicial system and will limit fundamental liberties such as freedom of expression.

There has been no public demand for the Bill of Rights. I cannot understand why the Government felt that it had to bring it in. There has been no public dissatisfaction with current legal and legislative protections of rights and no evidence has been put forward that human rights are under attack. The Federal Government gave Australians no time to consider this legislation, which is supposed to protect their civil liberties, before bringing it into the House of Representatives. The legislation was available for less than a month before it was rammed through the House. The House was given only one day to consider the Bill of Rights and the Government had Parliament sit until 3 a.m. to ensure the prompt passage of the Bill. Inadequate time was also given to State governments, legal bodies, community organisations and other interests to assess the implications of these changes.

The Bill omits many important rights. Labor members of Parliament voted against Opposition amendments in the House of Representatives which were intended: First, to confer the widest possible protection on the family; secondly, to protect the right of people to own property, or to be protected from acquisition of private property on other than just terms; thirdly, to protect individuals from discrimination at the work place by reason of their decision not to join a union, or generally to protect their employment opportunities when they freely elect not to be members of a union; fourthly, to protect the right of Australians to freely and fully utilise their natural wealth and to dispose of it as they see fit; and fifthly, to protect the rights of parents and guardians to choose private schools for their children and the right of individuals to establish direct private educational institutions.

According to the Constitution which was framed to protect people from power hungry governments, the people have given certain limited powers to the elected government and only in clearly defined areas. The Bill of Rights assumes a reversal of roles with the Government and its appointees, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, being not the servants of the people but their masters. Such an exchange of powers should be, constitutionally, only by the expressed will of the people-that is, by referendum. Tragically the Bill of Rights, by claiming to implement the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, can be forced upon Australia by the misuse of external affairs powers.

Much of the International Covenant, I regret to say, reflects communist influence, such as the omission of rights to own private property or to protection from compulsory acquisition of property or government interference in the use of land or housing. These omissions appear to be intentional and it is significant that none of these protections appear in the Australian Bill of Rights either. Mr Hawke and Mr Bowen know only too well that if the Australian public were asked whether they want a Bill of Rights for Australia, such a proposition would be resoundingly defeated, and deservedly so. I received a letter from the Returned Services League-I have no doubt that many other senators have also had correspondence from the RSL-which said:

Where is the clamour from the majority of Australians for reform and protection of our rights? Where is the threat to our society that government must legislate? Are Australians' rights and freedoms so threatened as to need such a radical change to our system, such an intrusion into the balance between the States and the Federal government.

The League, through its 270,000 members and in association with other ex-service organisations, says that it has not witnessed such demand. Public debate about the issue of a Bill of Rights for Australia has gone on since the early 1900s-ever since Federation-always with the same outcome. The majority of Australians have squashed the idea. The Australian Labor Party has had the introduction of a Bill of Rights in its Party platform since 1969 while the National and Liberal parties have maintained their opposition to it on the basis that Parliament and the judiciary are the best defenders of civil rights. It does not follow, either, that because a country has a Bill of Rights that country is safeguarding its citizens against infringement of those rights. Russia has a Bill of Rights but one could not say that the citizens of Russia enjoy freedom of expression or association.

The Bill of Rights is based on an international covenant and the High Court of Australia has given power for the legislation to override any section of the Constitution it feels it needs to in pursuit of its legislative goals. The Bill purports to implement certain provisions of the Inter- national Covenant on Civil and Political Rights but it has omitted in a number of places even some of the Covenant's protective qualifications. It would seem that if an existing right is not specifically included, we do not possess it.

What rights do we really now possess? I do not think it would hurt in this discussion to detail some of them. We have the right to freedom of thought, conscience, religion and expression; the right to own property; the right to utilise our natural wealth and talents and to dispose of them as we see fit; the right to marry and found a family; the right to rear our children and instruct them in the religion of our choice; the freedom of choice to join a union or an association or not to join a union or association; the right to question those who invade our rights and to invoke the protection of the courts; the right to a public and fair trial; the right to confront and question those who accuse us; and the right to call witnesses and refuse to testify against ourselves. It seems to me that we have so many rights that we do not need a Bill of Rights, and by introducing such a Bill I feel that we are trampling on the rights that we already possess. Sir Robert Menzies said:
To live in a common law country is in itself the very best guarantee of the rights of the individual.

The Covenant at least attempts a definition of existing rights-for example, rights existing under law, conventions, regulations or customs. Article 2 of the Bill, however, restricts protection to only those rights existing under a law. A whole range of United Nations conventions is being forced onto Australians without consultation with the people, the effect being that existing laws and freedoms are being negated by new regulations. In a sense, by accepting the incorrect notion that the Commonwealth has the authority to guarantee our rights and freedoms, we have already abandoned our claim to possess those rights as a matter of course. I refer to the rights that I have just detailed. We do have those rights under our Constitution. I read an interesting editorial in our local South Burnett paper headed `Rights . . . or Wrongs'-

TALK.START.PARA: —You probably wrote it, too, as well as reading it.
—No, I did not write it but it does accord with what I think, and it will do the honourable senator good to hear exactly what it says.
—I will bet you get another one next week, too.
—I hope that it writes about my speech. I shall send it a copy and hope that it will be written up well in the local South Burnett paper. This is what the editorial said:

SPEECH.PARA: Once you begin to define people's rights there is a danger you will limit them and that alone is reason enough to question real reasons for the Bill.

Consider the situation where, under the Bill, a complaint is made against you to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission. This proposed Bill empowers the commission to make you attend an inquiry, maintain secrecy about the person making the complaint; deny you the right to be represented at a hearing by legal counsel; and could require you to produce any documents, whether private or otherwise.
In addition, the commission could also deny you the right to not answer questions on the basis of self-incrimination ($1000 fine or three months in jail).

In cases where the commission makes a decision against you and you want to appeal to the courts . . . forget it because no appeal rights exist under this so-called bill of rights, a direct breach of existing common law rights regarding the presumption of innocence, the right to remain silent and the right to legal counsel.
The bill ensures a right to ``join'' a trade union but not the right to ``not'' join one. There is also no right to that fundamental part of our society-the right to private property.

However, I did hear Senator Haines say that the Australian Democrats might agree to a little amendment to put that in. It was very nice of her to say that; it is about the only thing the Democrats said this morning that I agreed with. The editorial continues:
The `Bill' makes it easier for activists to engage in wholesale social engineering, and it is a direct assault on our basic traditions.
The writer of the editorial in the South Burnett Times deserves commendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mature mind.

—A mature mind indeed. Common law traditions enshrine all the traditions and rights that the Bill is supposed to protect, so if the Australian people accept that the Government has the power to grant them rights, they simultaneously open the way for the present or a future government or a government body such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to regulate, modify or interpret those rights according to its own ideological commitment of the day. The Bill is intended to override the protection of the Constitution and that highlights why I maintain the need for the whole issue to be put to referendum so that the people can decide whether or not they want a Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Constitutionally the Federal Government possesses no powers other than those given to it by the people, which, of course, is a very good thing. The current misuse of the external affairs power is an exception and the only means by which these powers may properly be extended is by referendum, which is exactly what the Federal Government should be doing, as I have already said. However, this Bill of Rights assumes that the Federal Government has the constitutional power to give rights to people. Of course, it has no such power. Indeed, it would be an intrusion into areas outside the power delegated to it to do so.

To be quite blunt about it, the Bill of Rights seeks to demolish our federal system of government, destroy the Constitution, wipe out States' rights and centralise all power in Canberra. I think that we on this side of the Senate realise that it is the policy of the Australian Labor Party to do away with State governments. In fact the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) mentioned that in some of his Boyer lectures. The rights of all State governments and local government councils will come under direct attack from the Federal Government under the new Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill 1985. This Commission will have the power to compel State and local government employees to appear before it, to answer questions and to produce documents under pain of imprisonment or fine without automatic right to legal representation. Masquerading as protection, the Bill will expose the ordinary citizen to the almost unlimited potential of the Commission to deprive him or her of privacy, liberty, freedom of speech and, ultimately, of the many privileges that we take for granted in a free society.

This Bill and the associated Bills give far too much power to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I was rather hoping that the Australian Democrats would join the Opposition in voting against these Bills so that this new Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would not be needed. But I regret that they have said they will not go along with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party wants their support. Whatever the Labor Party wants, the Democrats do.

—It seems to me as though that could be the answer. Religious freedom is not guaranteed. It is omitted from Article 8, restricted in Article 5 to profession and practice within a religious community and qualified in Article 9 to be the right not to be coerced into adopting a religious belief. I believe that the latter is a very different thing from religious freedom. Parents' rights are not guaranteed. The only place where parents are mentioned is in the last sub-section of Article 14 in the Rights of the Child and then it only states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberty of parents . . . to ensure the religious and moral education of their children in conformity with their own convictions is to be respected.

I do not think we need a Bill of Rights to grant us the right to be married and to found a family. In fact, a family is not even defined. I do not believe that we need a Bill of Rights to grant our children the right to freedom of expression without interference and regardless of frontiers, whatever that means-that is in Article 7-and the freedom of association, Article 11, at an age to be determined by some quasi-judicial human rights commission. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has said that we should not worry about the commissioners that the Government will appoint to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. He said: `We will make sure that they are nice people'. I do not think that Mr Bowen is a very nice person to bring in a Bill of rights anyway. In fact, I have said around Queensland that I class it as a Bill of wrongs. That is something that I really feel very strongly about.

The handing over of power to a commission which is not elected by a democratic process undermines the whole structure of our society. I can understand the passage of such a Bill of Rights in Warsaw Pact countries where the people do not enjoy the freedoms that we take for granted. But for any government to bring forward this kind of suggestion and term it `rights' is to gravely misjudge the common sense of our community and reflects badly on the intentions of the governing body involved.

The Bill of Rights legislation is completely unnecessary in a country such as Australia. It merely outlines rights and freedoms which have already existed in this country and, beyond that, it takes away many of the rights which we have known as a matter of course. I oppose the Bill of Rights on the grounds that it is being introduced and forced on the people of Australia against their will. We do not need it and most people do not want it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the right to equality of voting power, Senator? That is a right which is fairly important, isn't it? It is not very important in Queensland, is it?
—I believe that in Queensland we have a system--
—You are different from everybody else, I know.

—I believe that the system that was originally brought in to Queensland by a Labor government many years ago certainly gives people-the 1,500,000 people, I might mention, who live away from the south-east corner of Queensland-a right to reasonable representation by their members of parliament. Look at the large areas that the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) and the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) represent in the other House. Gracious me! I do not know whether Senator Button realises that the area of Kennedy and Maranoa is about seven times the size of Victoria and Senator Button is one of twelve senators who represent Victoria. I feel that people are entitled to have reasonable and fair representation. That is what I believe they get in Queensland and that is why so many people from other States want to come and live in our State. I just leave that matter with the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this whole issue should be put to a referendum so that the people of Australia can be the best judges of what they want. I oppose this legislation and I condemn the Labor Government for the underhanded way in which the whole process of its introduction has been handled. I conclude with a quote from Sir Harry Gibbs, the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, who on 12 December 1984 said:
If society is tolerant and rational it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.
