DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Delays in Court Procedures-Naval Personnel: Incidence of Cancer

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) to convey a question to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). I am doing this at the adjournment stage because I wish also to incorporate in Hansard two letters so that they may be included with it. I have had recent correspondence with the Attorney- General about what amount to delays in court procedures in the Australian Capital Territory. He responded to one of the matters I raised but I do not think he has found a solution. The matter related to a judgment in the Supreme Court. It was well over 12 months from when the case was heard but no judgment had been given. That, of course, is very distressing for the parties involved. The two letters I wish to incorporate today each relate to the functioning of the coroners court. I have copies of those letters from which I have deleted the address and the signature of the constituents because I do not believe it is necessary or reasonable for those details to be made public.

SPEECH.PARA: One refers to the death of a daughter on 24 June 1985 in relation to which there has still been no coronial inquiry and the girl's parents have not been able to obtain a death certificate or get the matter completed or to find out why the matter has been so delayed. I am sure the Minister will appreciate how distressing this must be. I am sure he will also appreciate that there must be some occasions when the coronial matters are complicated and take a long time to resolve. If that is the case, I think there must be some means by which parents or other relatives could be advised of what the problems are and how long the delays are likely to be.

The other letter relates to an inquest into the death of the mother-in-law of a constituent who wrote to me about the matter. The death occurred in December 1984 and the relatives were complaining particularly of what occurred at the court on 21 October 1985. They were told to be at the court at 9.45 a.m. At 4 p.m. the same day they were told that the matter would not be dealt with that day. Again, in the circumstances of being reminded so closely of the death of the relative, it was a very distressing occasion. Is it that the coronial section of the court is not adequately staffed? Is it that the police in that area are not able to maintain the work load? I ask the Attorney-General to look into the functioning of the coroners court. If he finds that a lack of police efficiency is causing these delays, I ask him to take up the matter with the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) and ask him to intervene. It seems to me that the problems which are being faced by people indicate that this matter needs to be examined. I hope that he will take action of that matter as quickly as possible.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two letters, one addressed to the Chief Magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory Law Courts and the other to the Attorney-General, so that without my having to read them in detail the information will be available to the Senate.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
Mr Cahill
Chief Magistrate
ACT Law Courts
PO Box 370
CANBERRA CITY ACT 2601
Sir,
I am writing to you with a complaint of procedures at the Coroner's Court held on Monday 21 October 1985.

My wife was informed by letter, dated 9 October 1985, that an inquest into the death of her mother would be held on Monday, 21 October 1985 commencing at 10.00 am. I decided to attend the hearing on my wife's behalf and duly arrived at the Coroner's Court at 9.45 am, only to be told that nobody could tell me in which order the cases would be held, and that I would have to wait until the case was called.

At 4.05 pm, after all of the other cases had been dealt with, the Detective investigating my Mother-in-Law's death (Det. J. Matheison) entered the courtroom, only to be told that the case would have to be re-scheduled for a date to be fixed. I was informed verbally the following morning by the Coroner's officer, Sgt. J. Nolan, that the medical evidence for the case had in fact been heard, and that the remainder of the case would have taken no more than 10 or 15 minutes.

I was told verbally in August of this year, that toxicology tests in relation to my Mother-in-Law's death were done on 16 July 1985, some seven months after her death, but that the date of the inquest could not be set until the toxicology report was prepared, and the toxicologist (who I understand now works in Sydney) would be available. The earliest date was 21 October 1985, some 10 months after my Mother-in-Law's death.
My Mother-in-Law died in December 1984, and under the circumstances, I hope you can appreciate that this had a very detrimental effect on my wife, both mentally and physically.

Without an inquest, we have no death certificate, and without a death certificate we have had delays in the administration of my Mother-in-Law's estate. These delays do nothing except aggravate the mental health of my wife. Now, my wife and I find we have to wait again for another inquest, with no guarantee that the case will be heard anyway. Surely cases could be scheduled in order of date of death, but with simple cases scheduled first. Most of yesterday appeared to be taken up with a case involving two deaths as a result of a traffic accident which occurred on 26 March 1985, 3 months after my Mother-in-Law's death, and judging by the number of witnesses and solicitors involved, it appeared to be a relatively complex case.
Mr Cahill, I am sick of waiting, my wife is getting sick from waiting, when can we have our case heard?

Dear Mr Bowen,
I am writing to you concerning the operations of the Coroners' Court in the ACT, or more specifically the non-operation of the Court.

Following the death of my daughter in Royal Canberra Hospital on 24 June 1985, a coronial enquiry was necessary to establish the cause of death before a death certificate could be issued. As some seven months have now elapsed it is reasonable to expect that what should have been a reasonably simple administrative task would have been completed by the coroner by now. That is not the case and I am advised that there is something of a backlog of cases in the Coroners' Court.

As you can no doubt appreciate a delay of this nature is quite upsetting for parents and relatives of the deceased. There is also the problem that funeral benefits and so on cannot be claimed unless a death certificate is available. I understand that in certain cases this has led to bereaved relatives suffering unnecessary financial hardship.

Being an officer of the Department of Finance, I am well aware of the resource constraints that face public sector managers but I would seriously question the competence and managerial ability of any public service manager and, indeed, Minister who allowed the situation to deteriorate to the extent that it obviously has in the case of the operations of the Coroners' Court in the Australian Capital Territory. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 11 February, I placed on notice a question asking, firstly, how many serving and former Royal Australian Navy personnel have died from cancer or cancer related diseases since July 1984 and, secondly, how many of these personnel served at any time at naval shore radio stations with high-powered radio transmitters. The Navy is what one might call a closed ship, and I say that without intending to make a pun. But I understand that at present the Navy is buzzing with concern about a number of men who have died in the last 12 months or so of cancer. On investigation I understand it turns out that they have all worked at some time or other at naval shore radio stations which have high-powered radio transmitters.

SPEECH.PARA: This has caused Navy personnel suddenly to start to panic about whether there is some relationship between cancer and the nature of their work. This has also caused those who had worked on radio stations to panic as to whether there might be some direct relationship. I do not want to cause any panic in the community generally or in the naval community-quite the contrary. I do not intend in any way to raise this matter as scare tactics. It may very well be that such deaths have only to do with the normal proportion of people in the community who at a particular age would die of cancer anyway.

I also wish to make clear that I have no knowledge of what types of cancer are involved, so I am not able to say whether they are the same sorts of cancers and that there appears to be any relationship. On the contrary. This matter has been raised with me and I have endeavoured to pour cold water on the questioner by pointing out to him that three females of my acquaintance have died of cancer in the last 12 months. That may relate to the age of those females and percentages within the community. Nevertheless, I understand that there is grave concern among naval personnel who have served at shore naval radio stations with high-powered radio transmitters.

I understand that it has been common practice to place an unconnected neon tube near radio masts as a transmission warning and that these tubes light up during transmission-a good warning of transmissions in progress but also illustrative of the power of such emissions. In posing the question, what I seek from the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is some assurance that the Government will cause to be undertaken a thorough investigation into the naval and ex-naval personnel who have contracted cancer or cancer related diseases to see whether there is any service related cause of high incidence of cancer, or particular forms of cancer, among serving and ex-naval personnel who have served at such naval radio stations, and whether there is a higher incidence among such personnel than among other naval personnel and ex-naval personnel.

Even that, of course, would not resolve the issue. There may be other service related causes. For example, I understand that it is common knowledge that in the past in most Australian warships asbestos was extensively used in lagging and insulation to reduce sweating of steel. I wonder whether there is any indication that the incidence of asbestos related cancer is higher among ex-naval personnel than in the other services. In fact, some comparisons should be made between ex-naval personnel and perhaps other people in similar healthy groups, such as former Air Force and Army personnel. Of course, the fitness standards for entry to the three Services would place the general health of these serviceman above the national average.

I am also reminded of other causes of exposure that cannot be ruled out in view of recent Swedish research into low level radiation and non-ionising radiation, such as overexposure to radiation emissions from cathode ray tubes, visual display terminals and radar emissions. It may be that the overall environment of living in a ship provides a combination of hazards that have not been identified. On the other hand-I hope that this is true-the number of recent cancer related deaths which have caused these ex-naval personnel concern is simply coincidental and some investigation will indicate that naval personnel are not exposed to any more hazard than is the population as a whole. I ask the Minister to seek from his colleague the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) information from both the United Kingdom and United States authorities to ascertain whether their navies have conducted any research in these areas and, in general, to undertake some in-depth examination of this issue as expeditiously as possible in the hope that these concerns will be relieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will certainly pass on the requests of both honourable senators and I think both issues are important. As a medical practitioner, I have memories of the treatment of medical practitioner witnesses by the courts over the years. I vividly remember one of my colleagues giving up two days work to go to Sydney to give evidence at a coroners inquiry only to be told, having sat there for four hours, that the matter had been adjourned and he could come back in a month's time. Similar things have happened to me. As Senator Reid implied, when this sort of thing happens in a coroners court, it is just not acceptable. Such courts should be conducted with expedition and sensitivity, and people should not be treated in the way people were apparently treated in this case. I shall seek the answers she requires from the Attorney-General (Senator Lionel Bowen).

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis raises more difficult problems. I suppose that the easiest problem to investigate of the problems Senator Lewis mentioned would be whether or not naval personnel have a high incidence of asbestos-related tumours. Mesothelioma is a very distinct tumour. The incidence of it could be detected. Any significant increase in incidence is likely to be related to asbestos. The possibility of high energy radio and communication waves causing carcinomas has been looked at overseas and is being looked at now. In some towns in the United States close to sources of such radiation there have been suggestions that there is a higher incidence of certain forms of carcinoma. I will certainly get the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to answer the questions raised by Senator Lewis about the possible increased incidence amongst Navy personnel, in particular, shore-based Navy personnel. But, as Senator Lewis implied, one would need to go elsewhere to get further information because of the very small population group involved.

I am always reminded of the past and the relationship between disease and environmental factors. Not only cancers are involved. They are but one example. The relationship has been drawn to the attention of the medical profession by people outside it who have noticed co- incidences of this type. Thalidomide was one example, as was the incidence of cancer amongst the watch dial painters caused by radiation early in this century. Both were drawn to the attention of the medical profession by people outside it. For those who are interested, I mention that the coincidence of kuru and the eating of human flesh in New Guinea was obviously known by all the people who had lived in the area for 40 years, but it took the medical profession and the medical investigators about six years to believe them. So it is important that we investigate such claims. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Defence.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
